1939
Source: Monroe County Beacon dated May 22, 1939
Sally Betts, the daughter of Philip ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Sally Betts, the daughter of Philip >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Rosanna Christman, was born in Seneca Township, Monroe County, on April 5, 1876, and died April 28, 1939, being at the time of her death 63 years and 23 days of age.
She was united in marriage with ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She was united in marriage with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Theodore Betts on April 25, 1900, and to this union seven children were born: Mrs. Florence Starr and Earl Betts, both of Quaker City, Ohio; Josie, Wanetta and Robert, of the home. Ben departed this life ten years ago and one child died in infancy.
About twenty years ago she became a ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> About twenty years ago she became a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Christian and lived a consistent and faithful Christian life until death. She was a devoted wife and a loving mother. She was loved by all who knew her.
She leaves to mourn, her husband and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She leaves to mourn, her husband and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 five children; three sisters and one brother; Mrs. John Ackerman, of Lewisville; Mrs. Barbara Morris, of Salesville; Mrs. Ed Miller of Quaker City, and George L. Christman, of Lewisville. She also leaves four grandchildren, other relatives and many friends.
 
Dearest ======= mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Dearest >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mother, thou hath left us,
Thou hast <<<<<<< HEAD anchored safe where storms are oer;
======= anchored safe where storms are o er; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
In that blessed home just over the way,
Where we hope <<<<<<< HEAD to meet to part no more.
======= to meet to part no more. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

V. A. Traylor. Burial was made in the Calais cemetery.
 

June 22, 1939X

MARRIAGE

Wehr-Christman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Announcement had been made of the marriage of Mina B. Wehr, the daughter of W. N. Wehr, Batesville and Benjamin H. Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. P. F. Christman, near Woodsfield. The couple was united in marriage at the First Methodist parsonage, June 1st, at Alexandria, Ky. Rev. W. S. Mitchell read the single ring ceremony. The bride wore a blue chiffon dress with accessories of white and her corsage was of white roses.

Mrs. Christman graduated from Batesville ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Christman graduated from Batesville >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 High School and Mr. Christman graduated from Woodsfield High School and Wilmington College. He has been teaching in the Monroe County Schools for several years.

 

 

January 16, 1939X

BIRTH

Lois Eleanor DeVoe

Source: Beacon

 

Mr. and Mrs. Virgil DeVoe have announced ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. Virgil DeVoe have announced >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the birth of a 6 3/4 pound daughter at their home at Lewisville on Wednesday, January 11th. She has been named Lois Eleanor. Mr. and Mrs. F. S. DeVoe and Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Weber of Lewisville are the grandparents.

 

1939X

DEATH

Raymond Albert Kahrig

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, April 1939

 

The angel of Death has again visited our home ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The angel of Death has again visited our home >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and called another sweet and beautiful life from our midst. It being the life of Raymond Albert, little son of Alfred and Gertrude Kahrig.

Raymond was born July 7, 1936 at his home ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Raymond was born July 7, 1936 at his home >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in Malaga Township, and departed this life at 7:30 p.m. Sunday, April 30, 1939, at the age of two years, nine months and twenty-three days. His death was caused by a short illness of influenza. He was baptized on August 30, 1936.

He leaves to mourn, his father and mother; ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He leaves to mourn, his father and mother; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two brothers, Marion six years and Lewis, fourteen months; and one sister, Lena, four years. He was preceded in death by a sister who died in infancy five years ago.

He also leaves his grandparents, Mr. and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He also leaves his grandparents, Mr. and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. George L. Christman; Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Kahrig; and great-grandfather, George Pfalzgraf; several aunts and uncles and a large number of cousins, besides many other friends.

Raymond was a lovely child and was loved ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Raymond was a lovely child and was loved >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by everyone who knew him. He had a smile for everyone. All was done that loving hands and medical skill could do to save him, yet he was taken away, leaving a vacant place that never can be filled. His passing so early in life is greatly mourned by relatives and all who knew him.

Short funeral services were held on ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Short funeral services were held on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Tuesday afternoon, May 2nd, at 1:00 o'clock at the home, with final services at St. John's Evangelical and Reformed Church, Summit Township, in charge of Rev. Wm. R. Walch, of Lewisville. Burial was made in the church cemetery.

No one knows how much we miss him;

Only those who have lost can tell

Of the grief that is born in silence,

For the one we loved so well.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> No one knows how much we miss him;

Only those who have lost can tell

Of the grief that is born in silence,

For the one we loved so well.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

We shall now be sad and lonely,

Since thy voice we hear no more;

But again we hope to meet thee,

On that bright eternal shore.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> We shall now be sad and lonely,

Since thy voice we hear no more;

But again we hope to meet thee,

DEATH

Mary Ackerman

Source:

 

Mrs. Herman Ackerman, nee Mary Niesz, was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Herman Ackerman, nee Mary Niesz, was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 born in Birmingham, now Pittsburgh, Pa. on June 11, 1843

At the age of three years, her parents moved to Monroe County, Ohio and located in Malaga Township where she resided until her death.

In 1862 she was married to Herman ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> At the age of three years, her parents moved to Monroe County, Ohio and located in Malaga Township where she resided until her death.

In 1862 she was married to Herman >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ackerman. This union was blessed with seven children; Anna Bintz, John Ackerman and Henry Ackerman of Somerton; Mary Christman of Lewisville; Matilda Seebach of Limaville; Clara Christman of Calais, and Benjamin Ackerman of Donora, Pa. Anna preceded her in death on March 1, 1896. Her husband preceded her in death on February 27, 1919.

Mrs. Ackerman died on Mrs. Ackerman died on June 22nd about 8:30 a.m. at the home of Mrs. Jacob Christman at the age of 96 years and 11 days.

She leaves to mourn her death, besides the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She leaves to mourn her death, besides the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 children, the following: Twenty-nine grandchildren, sixty-seven great-grandchildren one great-great-grandchild and a host of other relatives and friends.

At the age of 17, she made the trip from Germany to this country alone, settling in Woodsfield, Ohio. She was united in marriage with Karl Brubach on January 30, 1873. In 1923, they celebrated their golden wedding anniversary. Their union was blessed with two children: Henry Brubach and Mrs. Minnie Claus, of Lewisville. She was preceded in death by the son, Henry, who died the twelfth of September 1928; and her husband on the 21st of October 1933.

1940
Fred Norris
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, 1940
    <<<<<<< HEAD Fred Norris, aged 53, of Jackson Ridge, died Tuesday afternoon at 3:15 oclock ======= Fred Norris, aged 53, of Jackson Ridge, died Tuesday afternoon at 3:15 o clock >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in North Wheeling Hospital, where he had been receiving treatment since Thursday, August 15th, when he fell upon a scythe while sharpening it, being severely cut. He had undergone several blood transfusions.
    Mr. Norris was a lifelong resident of Monroe County and had a wide circle of friends and acquaintances.
    Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Marie Hawkins Norris and the following children: Mrs. Helen Ellis and James Norris, of Detroit, Michigan; Mrs. Wilma Byers of Martins Ferry; Luther Norris, of Columbus; Margaret and Ray, of the home. Two brothers, Walter and Clarence Norris, and his father, Isaac Norris, all of Woodsfield Route 4, also survive.
    <<<<<<< HEAD Funeral services will be conducted Friday afternoon at 2:00 oclock at the ======= Funeral services will be conducted Friday afternoon at 2:00 o clock at the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Neuhart Ridge Baptist Church with burial in the Church cemetery.
 
Belle Hoskinson, mother of Mrs. Okey Slider of Sardis, Ohio, was born near Sardis and passed away quietly at Homeworth, Ohio, on Wednesday morning, February 21, at 11:40 a.m.  She had been in failing health for several years and bedfast for the last two weeks.  The body arrived at the home of her daughter Mrs. Okey Slider at Sardis on Friday, February 23rd. Funeral services were held Saturday at 10:00 a.m. at the Sardis Methodist Church, State Route 7, Sardis. Burial was in the Mt. Olive Cemetery.  She is survived by the following children:  Mrs. Albert Jennie, Homeworth, Ohio, Mrs. Harry Slider, Paden City, W. Va., Mrs. Okey Bowen, Fly, Mrs. Ben Christopher, Alliance, Ohio, Mrs. Chas. Martin, North Benton, Ohio, Mr. A. R. Hoskinson of North [line appears to be missing] Hoskinson, Paden City, Mr. Charles Hoskinson of New Matamoras, Ohio, Mr. E. D. Hoskinson, Ambridge, Pa., Mr. J. W. Hoskinson, Crooksville, Ohio.  She was preceded in death by her husband twenty-six years ago, and one daughter one year ago.  She is also survived by forty-four grandchildren, and twenty-seven great grandchildren and two brothers, Mr. William Cooley of New Matamoras and Mr. Daniel Cooley of Paden City, W. Va., Composed by Charles Gardner, a grandchild.

1940X

DEATH

Melvin Philip Kahrig

Source: The Monroe County Beacon

The Angel of Death has again visited our home and called another sweet and beautiful life, that of Melvin Philip Kahrig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahrig, who was born on March 2, 1940 at the home on Woodsfield Route 3. He departed this life at 1:00 o'clock a.m. on Tuesday, March 12, 1940, at the age of 10 days.

He was baptized on March 3rd at ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was baptized on March 3rd at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 his home by Rev. Wm. R. Walch, pastor of St. John's Evangelical and Reformed Church.

Melvin leaves to mourn his father and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Melvin leaves to mourn his father and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 mother; one sister, Lena, four years old and two brothers, Marion seven years and Lewis, two years old.

He ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was preceded in death by a brother, Raymond, who died on April 30, 1939, and a sister who died in infancy, January 26, 1940.

He also leaves his grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kahrig; Mr. and Mrs. George L. Christman and great-grandfather, George Pfalzgraf, several aunts and uncles and a large number of cousins and other relatives. Although he was but a ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He also leaves his grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kahrig; Mr. and Mrs. George L. Christman and great-grandfather, George Pfalzgraf, several aunts and uncles and a large number of cousins and other relatives. Although he was but a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 small child he was loved by all who knew him. He leaves a vacant place that never can be filled. We here on earth did all we could to save his life, but our Heavenly Father had need of him and called him home.

Short funeral services were held on ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Short funeral services were held on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Wednesday morning, March 13th at 9:00 o'clock at the home, with final services at the St. John's Evangelical and Reformed Church, Summit Township, in charge of the pastor, Rev. Wm. R. Walch. Burial was made in the church cemetery.

We have lost our darling baby,

He has bade us all adieu;

He has gone to live in heaven,

And his form is lost to view.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> We have lost our darling baby,

He has bade us all adieu;

He has gone to live in heaven,

And his form is lost to view.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

Oh, that dear one, how we love him

Oh, how hard to give him up

But an angel came down for him

And removed him from our flock.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Oh, that dear one, how we love him

Oh, how hard to give him up

But an angel came down for him

And removed him from our flock.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

Sometimes we hear them calling

Sweetly calling you and me

From this land of toil and trouble

To that blest eternity.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Sometimes we hear them calling

Sweetly calling you and me

From this land of toil and trouble

To that blest eternity.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

1940 1940 >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 style='font-family:Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language: JA'>XXXXX

Forrest B. Mobberly and Mary Margaret Mobberly (nee Dillon)

Spirit of Democracy.  (April 4, 1940):

"Two Killed in Auto Accident near Newark, Ohio  Mr. & Mrs. Forrest Mobberly succumb after accident.  Mrs. Forrest Mobberly, daughter of Duncan Dillon of S. Main Street was instantly killed in an auto accident Wednesday.  Her husband, son of the late Mr. & Mrs. Milton Mobberly died Wednesday night in a Newark hospital having been critically injured in the wreck. 

 

Mr. & Mrs. Mobberly together with Donald Calville, the driver, and Miss Ruth Stallings and Mrs. Vincent Mascarilli, all of Steubenville, were enroute to Columbus when the accident occurred.  It is stated that their car skidded on slippery pavement and collided with a truck, near Kirkersville, about 15 miles south of Newark.

 

Mr. & Mrs. Mobberly are survived by two children, in addition to many relatives in Woodsfield and Graysville communities.  Mrs. Mobberly was 42.   (She was really 44 at the time of accident.)

 

The body of Mrs. Mobberly was brought to the home of her father this Thursday morning and the body of her husband will be brought to the Dillon home this afternoon.  No funeral arrangements have been made at this time.   

 

Double Funeral Held

Double funeral services held for Mr. & Mrs. Mobberly, victims in an auto accident were held Saturday afternoon.  Short services were held a thte home of Mrs. Mobberly's father, Duncan Dillon of S. Main Street at 2:00 and were followed by final rites at the Methodist Church with Rev. Mr. Rogers of Weirton, W.Va. as the principal officiating minister.  Burial was made in Oak Lawn Cemetery in Weirton.

 

Mr. & Mrs. Mobberly are survived by two daughters, Mrs. Paul Gilmore of Springboro and Miss Bernadine of the home.

 

Surviving Mrs. Mobberly besides her father Duncan Dillon, are brothers Lawrence or Woodsfield and Guy of Stuebenville.  Surviving Mr. Mobberly, who was the son of late Mr. & Mrs. Milton Mobberly of Graysville, are the following brothers and sisters, Mrs. B. L. Allen, of Independence, Kansas, Mrs. J. W. Allen of Woodsfield, Ohio, Mrs. W. R. Coss, Mrs. Harry Scott, J. Foster Mobberly of Zanesville an Errett Mobberly of Graysville.

 

In response to my question, "How did it happen that none of the kids were along?" Brenda Eva Reilley Hunsberger, the source of this article, wrote, "My grandmother, who was their daughter, was married with 3 children of her own.  My grandmother was 24 when they died and her sister, Bernadeen, was 14.  My grandmother took Bernadeen in after their deaths and finished raising her until she was an adult."  In a later e-mail message <<<<<<< HEAD Brenda wrote, My mom told me that the driver of the car hit the truck because the truck had run a stop sign and that it was a Coca-Cola truck. 

======= Brenda wrote, My mom told me that the driver of the car hit the truck because the truck had run a stop sign and that it was a Coca-Cola truck.  

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

1940 XXXXX

======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> XXXXX

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

Mary Mabel Mobley nee Pfeiffer

Mrs. Mary Mabel Mobley, 63, wife of Vincent Mobley, died at her home in Fulton Sunday night following an extended illness.  She was born in Monroe county, October 17,1877, the daughter of Adam and Hannah Jane Pfeiffer and was married to Mr, Mobley at Marietta on Nov, 28, 1894. The family had lived in Fulton for 16 years, moving there from Bedford.  She was a member of the Fulton Methodist church and the Pythian Sisters.

Surviving are four children, Addel Mobley, at home, and Mrs. Calvin Buell, of Fulton, and Mrs. Charles Forsley and Dewey F. Mobley, both of Marietta. a foster son, Charles Swartz, of Fulton. two sisters,Mrs. James Gordon (Jordan) of West Virginia,and Mrs.Emma Pfeiffer Briggs of Arkansas, and four brothers, Frank and Arthur of West Virginia, Lewis Pfeiffer, of Sabina, and Joseph Pfeiffer of Marietta.

Funeral services were held at the Methodist church in Fulton Wednesday afternoon. Burial was made in the Fulton cemetery,  (1940)

Louise Pfazgraf Gossage

Meredith Kahrig

Mr. and Mrs. George Kahrig of Lewisville ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. George Kahrig of Lewisville >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Route 2, are the proud parents of a l0-1/2 pound son, born on April 8th. 1940

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'>

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

Thomas Prall Lendon, for many years a resident of the Morristown-Flushing district, died Friday (June 14, 1940 ) at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Everett Wilson of near Morristown.  The funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock from the Wilson home. Rev. Charles Gray of the Henrysburg Methodist church conducted the services.  Sells, of Henrysburg, was in charge. Interment was made in St. Clairsville. Mr. Lendon was the son of Thomas and Amy (Seibert ) Lendon, his father being a native of Ireland.  He was born on March 2, 1858 in Washington, Pa.  Those bereaved by his death are four daughters, Mrs. George Ward of Columbus, Mrs. Jack Brenza of Cleveland, Mrs. Ross Diday of Bellaireand Mrs .Everett Wilson, three sons, Raymond, Wilbur, and Leonard, all of Flushing.  Two sisters Mrs. Rose Landers of Armstrong Mills and Mrs. Margaret Hendershot of Beallsville, one brother, Hudson Lendon of Glencoe.  Buried in: St. Clairsville Cemetery -- Buried on Tuesday because of bad weather.

William A. Lucas, died July 1940, born at Malaga Ohio, October 8, 1868, son of Alexander and Sara A. Tacker Lucas. Wife, Rose Lee Lucas preceded him in 1936. Children: Mrs. C. D. Brooks, Reginald R. Lucas, I. A. Lucas. Burial in Somerton Cemetery.

DEATH

Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, November 28,1940 Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
Funeral rites were held last Sunday ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral rites were held last Sunday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 for nine-year-old Alva Christman, Jr., victim Thanksgiving Day of a gunshot would inflicted by his brother, Emerson, aged eight.
The mishap occurred at the family home near Monroefield, at 10:30 a.m. Thursday. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The mishap occurred at the family home near Monroefield, at 10:30 a.m. Thursday. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Alva was playing with his dog when Emerson picked up a .22 caliber rifle, left leaning against the house by an uncle, Irvin Christman. The rifle discharged, hitting Alva in the head just behind the ear. He died at 2:45 p.m.
Funeral services were held at the ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral services were held at the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 home Sunday at 2:00 p.m. and then at Middle Church cemetery.

Surviving besides them are: Two brothers, Gerald and Emerson; two sisters, Shirley Jane and Eloise and the grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Kahrig and Mr. and Mrs. Fred Christman, all of Lewisville.

DEATH

Alva Junior Christman

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated February 3, 1941

Alva Junior Christman was born June 18, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Alva Junior Christman was born June 18, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1931, and died November 21, 1940, being at the time of his death nine years, five months and three days old. He was a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alva Christman, of near Monroefield, and was born in Seneca Township at the home of his grandfather, Fred Christman.

He leaves to mourn his sad departure, his ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He leaves to mourn his sad departure, his >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 father, mother, two brothers, Emerson and Gerald; two sisters, Eloise and Shirley Jean; his paternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred Christman; his maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kahrig; and one great-grandfather, George Pfalzgraf, besides a host of relatives and friends.

They body was removed to Bauer and Turner ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> They body was removed to Bauer and Turner >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Funeral Home, where it was prepared for burial and returned to the home on Friday afternoon.

Short services were held at the home at ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Short services were held at the home at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 2:00 o'clock, Sunday, with final services being held at Middle Evangelical and Reformed Church in charge of Rev. Wm. R. Walch. Interment was in the church cemetery.

Now it's hard for us to say--Junior was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Now it's hard for us to say--Junior was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 accidentally shot on Thanksgiving Day.

He was a good boy and was a great help not ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was a good boy and was a great help not >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 only to his father and mother but to everyone that he could do something for, he sure would and always seemed to be wanting to do more. He spent many of his days with Grandpa and Grandma Christman of whom he thought a lot of.

He was attending the Calais School and was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was attending the Calais School and was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in the third grade. He was proud of his teach, Miss Eunice Hannahs, who was his teacher for all three years.

We know he is sadly missed not just here at home but by all who knew him..

His friendly smiles, his kindly way

Are pleasant to recall

He had a kind word for everyone

And died beloved by all.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> We know he is sadly missed not just here at home but by all who knew him..

His friendly smiles, his kindly way

Are pleasant to recall

He had a kind word for everyone

And died beloved by all.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

A dear one from us is gone

Gone, yes, forevermore;

But we know some day we will meet him

On that bright and happy shore.

Gone, yes, forevermore;

But we know some day we will meet him

Moffett, Oliver
SOURCE: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, February,1941
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Oliver Moffett, son of Peter and Martha Moffett, was born near Antioch,Ohio July 4, 1865, and passed away at his home on east ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Oliver Moffett, son of Peter and Martha Moffett, was born near Antioch,Ohio July 4, 1865, and passed away at his home on east >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 church street,Woodsfield, Wednesday evening, January 29, 1941, being at the time of his death 75 years, 6 months and 25 days of age. He lived in Paden city, West Virginia, quite a while before moving to woodsfield six years ago.
He was united in marriage with Edna ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> He was united in marriage with Edna >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Eikelberry on july 26,1905, and to this union two children were born: Mrs. Freda Cecil, of Paden city, and sergeant Everett E. Moffett, of Camp Blanding, Florida.
Mr. Moffett was a kind husband and father,a good neighbor and true friend. He ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Moffett was a kind husband and father,a good neighbor and true friend. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was interested in others and always willing to help in the time of need.
He leaves to mourn, his wife, two ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> He leaves to mourn, his wife, two >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 children, one brother, J. Wesley Moffett,of Sardis, Ohio, route 1 and six grandchildren. besides these,he leaves other relatives and many friends.
 
"Sweetly rest from all thy labor,
far from every grief and pain;
we will often think about you,
while we here on earth remain."
 
Funeral services were conducted at the Moffett church by minister J. V. A. Traylor, Saturday afternoon, February 1st, at 2:00 o'clock. Burial was made in the church cemetery.
 
Card of thanks
We desire to thank all who assisted us in any way during the illness and at the time of the death of our husband and father. We appreciate the kindness of those who gave flowers and those who furnished cars and also appreciate the courtesy of Bauer and Turner. We thank brother Traylor for his words of comfort and thank him and Mrs. Traylor for their songs.--Mrs. Moffett and children

DEATH
Name: Margaret E. Claus, nee Hoff
Source: Newspaper clipping of February 1941
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
Life is a drop from the river,
That rises in mist oer the lea,
A moment in space of quiver,
Then falls on the breast of the sea,
It was- It is-now gone forever,
Yet ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Life is a drop from the river,
That rises in mist o er the lea,
A moment in space of quiver,
Then falls on the breast of the sea,
It was- It is-now gone forever,
Yet >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 lives through eternity.
On Saturday morning, February 8, 1941, at six oclock the death angel entered our home and called our dear and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On Saturday morning, February 8, 1941, at six o clock the death angel entered our home and called our dear and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 beloved wife and mother to her home to eternal rest at the age of 79 years, 9 months and 1 day.
Margarite E. Hoff Claus, the eldest ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Margarite E. Hoff Claus, the eldest >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughter of Frederic and Margarite Zimmerle Hoff, was born on May 7, 1861, in Washington County, near Lebanon, Ohio.
She was united in marriage with ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She was united in marriage with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Charles Claus, on June 14, 1883, who was her companion through 58 years of married life.
She leaves to mourn her sad departure her aged ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She leaves to mourn her sad departure her aged >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 companion; two children, Oswald A. Claus, of Pittsburg; and Bertha Reich, of Miltonsburg, Ohio; the following grandchildren, Mrs. Charlotte Brown and Miss Mildred Claus of Longview, Texas; Arthur Reich, of Miltonsburg and Vernon Reich of Lewisville; four great grandchildren, Richard and Charles Brown and Alice and Janet Reich. The following sisters and brother survive: Mrs. Elizabeth Peters, of Miltonsburg; Mrs. Mary Zerger, of Woodsfield, and Fred W. Hoff, of Alliance, Ohio, also five nieces and four nephews.
The deceased was a member of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, being baptized and confirmed at an early age. She was also a member of the Senior Womens Union of the local Church. She led ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The deceased was a member of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, being baptized and confirmed at an early age. She was also a member of the Senior Women s Union of the local Church. She led >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 a consistent Christian life and was ready to go when God called her home. She was a kind and loving Mother and was loved and respected by all who knew her. All that could be done was done with kind and willing hands but to no avail; but Mother is in heaven and if we live for our God we shall meet her in her eternal home never more to part.
Brief funeral services were held at the family home, Monday afternoon at 2:00 oclock, followed by additional services at St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, with the Reverend R. W. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Brief funeral services were held at the family home, Monday afternoon at 2:00 o clock, followed by additional services at St. Paul s Evangelical and Reformed Church, with the Reverend R. W. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Jungfer, Jr., her pastor officiating. Burial was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

1941X
Quaker City Man Dies in Wheeling
Quaker City, O.- Quaker City, O.-Rodney O. Gibson, 49, of near Quaker City, died early
this morning at the Ohio Valley General hospital at Wheeling from heart
trouble.
A well known farmer of this vicinity, he ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> A well known farmer of this vicinity, he >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 served with the A.E.F. during
the World war.
He was a member of the Quaker City ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was a member of the Quaker City >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Methodist church and the Masonic and
Eastern Star <<<<<<< HEAD lodges here.
Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Esther ======= lodges here.
Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Esther >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Gibson, of the home, and two
brothers, Ralph Gibson, of Del Rey, Calif., and Guy Gibson of Kerman, Calif.
Funeral services will be held at 1:30 ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services will be held at 1:30 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 o'clock Sunday afternoon at the
home. Burial will be in the Friends cemetery, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Burial will be in the Friends cemetery, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Quaker City.
[Source: The Times Recorder, Zanesville, Ohio, Saturday, May 17, 1941, p. 6]
 
1941
MARRIAGE
Names: Mr. Harry E. Taylor
and Miss ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Names: Mr. Harry E. Taylor
and Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mary Estella Ackerman
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Woodsfield, Ohio, July 17, 1941
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Reverend Harry M. Wilson, pastor of First Church of Christ, Caldwell, Ohio, officiated at the marriage of Miss Mary Estella Ackerman and Harry E. Taylor, both of Woodsfield, at the home of the pastor in Caldwell, the single ring ceremony being read at 6:00 oclock Sunday ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Reverend Harry M. Wilson, pastor of First Church of Christ, Caldwell, Ohio, officiated at the marriage of Miss Mary Estella Ackerman and Harry E. Taylor, both of Woodsfield, at the home of the pastor in Caldwell, the single ring ceremony being read at 6:00 o clock Sunday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 evening, July 13th.
Mr. and Mrs. Rolland Mann, of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. and Mrs. Rolland Mann, of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Canton, Ohio, brother-in-law and sister of the groom were the only attendants.
The bride was attractively attired ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The bride was attractively attired >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in a street-length dress of poudre blue with white accessories. Her attendant, Mrs. Mann, was also dressed in blue and white accessories.
The bride is a daughter of Mr. and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The bride is a daughter of Mr. and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Henry Ackerman, superintendent and matron of the Monroe County Home. She is an operator in the Duchess Beauty Salon, Woodsfield. The groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Taylor, of North Main Street, Woodsfield.
The happy couple plan to make their ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The happy couple plan to make their >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 home in Canton, where Mr. Taylor has employment with the Timken Roller Bearing Company.
Their many friends extend congratulations.
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Their many friends extend congratulations. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
1941XXXXX
Highman - Bigler
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Oh. dated, Thurs. July 31, 1941
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Alma Bigler,
of Woodsfield and Hamilton Highman, of the Woodsfield-Graysville Road.
The ceremony was performed Saturday night at 11:30 o'clock at the home
of the bride in the presence of Everett Highman, son of the
bridegroom: Lawrence Bigler, a son of the bride; Mrs. J.V.A. Traylor
and daugthter Barbara, of Woodsfield. Minister J.V.A. Traylor
officiated at the exchange of the Vow.
The bride was attired in a beige crepe dress with which she wore
brown accessories.
The bride is employed as a clerk in the M. and K. Store in
Woodsfield, while her husband is employed with the State Highway
Department in Monroe County.
The couple will make their home at the home of the bride until
September 1, when they will move to Mr. Highman's home on the
Graysville-Woodsfield Road.
 
1941X
Clarence Graham, hubby to Gail C. Betts
Well known Batesville Man Dies Suddenly
Clarence Huber (Hube) Graham, 55, dropped ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Clarence Huber (Hube) Graham, 55, dropped >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 death at 2:30 Tuesday
afternoon at Batesville, while waiting on a customer at the Long hardware
store, where he <<<<<<< HEAD had been employed for about a month. The ======= had been employed for about a month. The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 heart attack came
without warning, and death occurred instantly.
Mr. Graham had been in failing health for ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Graham had been in failing health for >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 sometime, but was thought to
be recovering. About three years ago he was forced to give up his work at
the Hartley hardware <<<<<<< HEAD store in Quaker city because of his health. ======= store in Quaker city because of his health. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 By trade
he was a carpenter, but had been employed in various capacities requiring mechanical skill and knowledge.
Mr. Graham was a native of Nobel county, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Graham was a native of Nobel county, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and well-known and like in
this section, where his friendly disposition and quiet personality made him many friends.
Mr. Graham has twice married, his first ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Graham has twice married, his first >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wife, Gail Betts Graham,
preceding him <<<<<<< HEAD in death in 1932. Three children, born to this union survive, Kenneth and Herschel Graham and Mrs. Harold McKee, all of Zanesville. His widow, Mrs. Dorothy Sells Graham, of Batesville survives him. ======= in death in 1932. Three children, born to this union survive, Kenneth and Herschel Graham and Mrs. Harold McKee, all of Zanesville. His widow, Mrs. Dorothy Sells Graham, of Batesville survives him. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 In addition he leaves four brothers, John and Howard Graham of Barnesville, Riley Graham of Huntington, W. Va., and Orville Graham, and three sisters, Mrs. Henry Arick of near Batesville, Mrs. Charles Reed and Mrs. William Powell of
Barnesville.
He was superintendent of the Batesville ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was superintendent of the Batesville >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Methodist church Sunday school.
H was a member of the F & A. M. lodge of Quaker City and was a Scottish Rite
and 32 degree Mason.
Services will be held at 2 p.m. Friday at ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Services will be held at 2 p.m. Friday at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the Batesville Methodist
church, with burial at the Batesville cemetery.
Note: the name Orville should be Oril; 2nd wife, Dorothy's name is actually
Dorothy (Hunt) Sells.
[Source: article shared by Evelena Brown; dated March 17]
 
 

1942X

BIRTH

Lester Lee Christman

Source: Beacon, Feb 1942

 

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert A. Christman, of Fly ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert A. Christman, of Fly >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Route 1, announce the arrival of a 10 lb, son, born Friday, February 20th. The new arrival has been named Lester Lee. Mrs. Christman will be remembered as the former Miss Theodora Mellott. Grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Mellott, of Cameron, and Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Christman, of Quaker City.

 
1942
F. C. Stewart Frederick Clark Stewart, aged 61, ======= "Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Frederick Clark Stewart, aged 61, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of 544 Maple Avenue, passed away very suddenly at 11:45 Christmas Eve, at his home.  He was well-known in this community as he had a been a U. S. letter carrier for twenty-four years prior to his recent retirement in August, 1942.  His cordial greeting and happy smile along his mail route will be remembered by those with whom his occupation brought him into daily contact.  Mr. Stewart was well-known in Masonic circles, being Worshipful Master of Wetzel Lodge No. 39, A. F. & A. M. for two terms, also Deputy Grand Master for this Masonic district and at the time of his death was Secretary of the Masonic Association.  Deceased was a native of Monroe County, Ohio, a son of James M. and Eliza Ellen Stewart.  He came to Paden Valley with his parents when about 15 years of age, later moving to New Martinsville.  In his early years he was employed by the Snodgrass Grocery Store, Rymer Brothers and the Josephus Clark Department Store.  He traveled for the New Martinsville Wholesale Grocery Company, later being a merchant himself, owning a grocery store on Main Street.  Twenty-four years ago he entered the service of the U. S. Mails, at which he worked until his retirement.  On November 2, 1904, he was united in marriage to Rhoda Elizabeth Moore.  His wife survives him, also one daughter, Ruby E. Stewart of Wheeling, and one son Ralph M. Stewart of Parsons, W. Va., one granddaughter, Miss Carolyn Jean Stewart of Parsons, three sisters, Mrs. John Clark of New Martinsville, W. Va., Mrs. M. W. Slider of Atwater, Ohio, and Mrs. J. C. Farr of Newark, Ohio, one brother John H. Stewart of Pine Grove, WV.  [Died in 1942]
 
John Richard Johnson
Barnesville Enterprise - April 23, 1942; page 4- OBITUARY
John Richard Johnson for the past 32 years an employee of the Watt Foundry, died Friday morning at 2 o'clock at his home at 602 Wiley Avenue.  The funeral services were held from the Campbell Funeral Home Sunday afternoon at half past one.  They were conducted by Rev. F. B. Gilhousen, pastor of the Main Street Methodist church, and interment was made in the cemetery at Calais.  Mr. Johnson was the son of James and Nancy Elizabeth Johnson, and was born at Miltonsburg on August 14, 1867.  He was married in February 1887 to Louvina Johnson, who survives him. 
They were the parents of ten children, one son, Victor, preceding his father in death.  Bereaved by Mr. Johnson's death are the widow, the following children, Allen Johnson of Lewisville, R. D., Mrs. Louise Stephens, Mrs. Nettie Taylor, Mrs. Arizona Morris, William Johnson, Miles Johnson, Okey Johnson, and Tallmadge Johnson, all of Barnesville, and Miss Juanita Johnson of the home, 22 grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and one brother, James Johnson of Summerfield, R. D.
 
 
 
1942
DEATH
Name: Mrs. Phillip Zerger
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Issue: Woodsfield, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Issue: Woodsfield, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio, Thursday, May 28, 1942
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Mrs. Phillip Zerger, aged 69 years, passed away at 7:30 oclock, Thursday morning of last week, May 21, 1942, at ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Phillip Zerger, aged 69 years, passed away at 7:30 o clock, Thursday morning of last week, May 21, 1942, at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 her home on Oaklawn Avenue, Woodsfield. She had been seriously ill but her condition was thought to be improving satisfactorily and her death came as a severe shock to her family and scores of friends.
She is survived by her husband; two ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She is survived by her husband; two >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 sons, Herman and Raymond, both of Woodsfield; four grandchildren, Doris, Ruth, Paul and Junior Zerger all of Woodsfield; one brother, Fred Hoff of Alliance and one sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Peters of Miltonsburg, Ohio.
Funeral services were held at 2:00 oclock Sunday afternoon at the Galbraith funeral home in charge of the Reverend John H. Hose, pastor of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed Church, assisted by the Reverend F. A. Reigle, of Lewisville. Burial was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral services were held at 2:00 o clock Sunday afternoon at the Galbraith funeral home in charge of the Reverend John H. Hose, pastor of St. Paul s Evangelical and Reformed Church, assisted by the Reverend F. A. Reigle, of Lewisville. Burial was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 

September 7, 1942X

BIRTH

Carol Sue Heft

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Heft, of Woodsfield, are the parents of a 7 and one-fourth pound daughter, named Carol Sue, born in Marietta Memorial Hospital, at 8:00 o'clock Thursday evening, September 3rd. 1942
Philip Gertler
Philip Gertler Dies at Ozark
September 10, 1942
Spirit of Democracy September 1942
Phillip W. Gertler, aged 75 years, passed ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Spirit of Democracy September 1942
Phillip W. Gertler, aged 75 years, passed >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 away at his home at Ozark at 3:30 o'clock this Thursday morning. He had suffered a paralytic stroke on last Thursday morning.
Surviving are his wife; one daughter, Mrs. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving are his wife; one daughter, Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Newell Paine, of the home; two grandsons, Larry William and Frank Gertler Paine, also of the home; one brother, George Gertler, Woodsfield, and one sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Moore of Ozark.
Short funeral services at the home Saturday afternoon will be followed by final rites at St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Woodsfield, at 2:00 o'clock. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Short funeral services at the home Saturday afternoon will be followed by final rites at St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Woodsfield, at 2:00 o'clock. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Rev. John H. Hose will be in charge of the services and burial will be made in Oaklawn Cemetery.
Mr. Gertler was a member of St. Paul's ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Gertler was a member of St. Paul's >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Church and a member of Jerusalem K. of P. Lodge.
 

October 22, 1942X

DEATH

Cora Christman

Source: Spirit of Democracy

Mrs. Cora Christman, aged 63 years, wife ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Cora Christman, aged 63 years, wife >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Philip Christman of near Calais, died at 12:30 o'clock on Thursday morning October 15th, at her home, following a short illness due to a stroke suffered the previous Saturday.

She is survived by her husband; six ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She is survived by her husband; six >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 children: Mrs. Chas Neuhart and Ben Christman of Batesville; Irvil of Canton; Bernard of Bolivar, Ohio; Walter of near the home; and Philip who is in camp in North Carolina. There are also four sisters and three brothers.

Funeral services were held at the late ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held at the late >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 home Sunday afternoon and burial was made in the Calais Cemetery.

 
1942
James M. Gray
Rites Held Sunday
Spirit of Democracy ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Spirit of Democracy >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 October 15, 1942
James M. Gray, aged eighty years, passed ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> James M. Gray, aged eighty years, passed >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 away last Friday afternoon at four o'clock, at his home, west of Woodsfield, on the Woodsfield and Lewisville road. He had been ill for several years and serious for a few weeks.
He is survived by his widow and one ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He is survived by his widow and one >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughter, Miss Mary of the home besides many other relatives and friends.
Funeral services were held on Sunday ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held on Sunday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 afternoon at 2:00 o'clock at the late home, with Rev. Theodore Peterson officiating. Burial was made in The Oaklawn Cemetery with W. P. Galbraith in charge.
Mr. Gray was a self-reliant industrious ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Gray was a self-reliant industrious >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 citizen, honorable and friendly in all his relations with others. As a business man, both in a store near Graysville and in a retail feed business, near his late home, he enjoyed the high confidence of his patrons.
Mr. Gray was a member of The Methodist Church ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Gray was a member of The Methodist Church >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 but for the past several years was prevented by illness from attendance at church services.
 

1942X

DEATH

Frederick Koehler

Source: <<<<<<< HEAD November 1942, (Married Louise ======= November 1942, (Married Louise >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf, daughter of George M. Pfalgraf)

Frederick Koehler was born on December 21, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Frederick Koehler was born on December 21, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1854 in Oldenberg, Germany, the son of Peter and Elizabeth Koehler, nee Petric. He departed this life on November 7, 1942 at his home near Lewisville at the age of 87 years, 10 months and 17 days.

He was united in Holy Matrimony with ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was united in Holy Matrimony with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Louisa Pfalzgraf on January 26, 1987 and to this union were born three children - one son and two daughters. One of the daughters died in infancy. Mrs. Koehler preceded him in death about ten years ago.

Mr. Koehler's passing is mourned by his ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Koehler's passing is mourned by his >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 brother, Nicholas Koehler, also by three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

After coming to Monroe County with his ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> After coming to Monroe County with his >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 parents at the age of three years, he spent his entire life in this vicinity. He had always been engaged in farming. He was a member of the Evangelical Church at Lewisville.

 

"There is no death. The stars go down

To rise upon some fairer shore;

And bright in Heaven's jeweled crown

They shine forever more."

Services to his memory were conducted on ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> "There is no death. The stars go down

To rise upon some fairer shore;

And bright in Heaven's jeweled crown

They shine forever more."

Services to his memory were conducted on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Wednesday, November 11, in St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church, Woodsfield, by the Rev. John Hose. Interment was in Oaklawn Cemetery.

Mrs. J. R. Betts, Former Resident, Dies.
Funeral services for Mrs. Mary Betts, 44, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services for Mrs. Mary Betts, 44, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Columbus were held Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock at the Campbell funeral home in Barnesville, with
Rev. D. B. Davidson in charge. Burial was made in Friends cemetery in Quaker
City.
Mrs. Betts, wife of Jess R. Betts died ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Betts, wife of Jess R. Betts died >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 early Sunday morning in the
University hospital, Columbus, following a short illness developing in
pneumonia. A former resident of Quaker City, after which she resided in
Barnesville several years, she had only lived in Columbus since July of this
year. She was a daughter of George and Emma Wehr McPeek and was born in
Batesville.
In addition to her husband, she is ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> In addition to her husband, she is >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 survived by two children, J. Willard
and Mrs. Betty Atkinson of Columbus; three sisters, Mrs. Robert Watson,
Quaker City R.D., and Mrs. Clarence Lippert, Columbus and Mrs. Harry Stotts,
Quaker City <<<<<<< HEAD R.D. A brother and sister are deceased. Many local friends
======= R.D. A brother and sister are deceased. Many local friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
will sorrow at her untimely passing.
[Source: Shared by Evelena Brown; dated September 20, 1942]

======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Dec. 17, 1942 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Charles Gadd, aged 51, died at his home in Detroit, Monday, December 7, 1942. Death followed a cerebral hemorrhage. However he had not been well ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Charles Gadd, aged 51, died at his home in Detroit, Monday, December 7, 1942. Death followed a cerebral hemorrhage. However he had not been well >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 for several months. He was a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lee Gadd, former residents of this place. His mother died last July at Zanesville, Ohio.
Besides his wife, he is survived by ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Besides his wife, he is survived by >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 one daughter, also one sister and three brothers. They are Mrs. August Poehlman, of Woodsfield; Guy, of Detroit; Clarence and Clifford of Zanesville.
Charles was a building contractor in Detroit for several years, a member of the Masonic Lodge and is kindly remembered by many friends in Monroe County. He went to Detroit about thirty years ago.

1942
DEATH
Name:Mrs. Elizabeth Rasche
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, OH, Thurs., Dec. 17, 1942
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Dec. 17, 1942 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Mrs. Elizabeth Rasche, aged 84 ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Elizabeth Rasche, aged 84 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 years, of Burlington, Iowa, passed away in a hospital at Burlington on Thursday night, December 10, 1942, due to a broken hip sustained about two weeks prior to her death.
She is survived by five children and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She is survived by five children and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 one sister Mrs. Kathryn Arnold of Woodsfield. Mrs. Charles F. Bott, of east of Woodsfield is a niece. Mrs. Rasche was a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Neuhart of Woodsfield.
Funeral services were held at Burlington on Sunday and burial was made there. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral services were held at Burlington on Sunday and burial was made there. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
1942
DEATH
Name: D. E. Gehrig
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, OH, Thurs., Dec. 17, 1942
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Dec. 17, 1942 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
D. E. Gehrig, aged 75 years, passed away at 8:00 oclock Sunday, December 13, 1942, at his home near Hannibal, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> D. E. Gehrig, aged 75 years, passed away at 8:00 o clock Sunday, December 13, 1942, at his home near Hannibal, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters, Mrs. Hazel Myers of Parkersburg, West Virginia, and Miss Corene of the home and three sons, Dale of Woodsfield; Willis in the United States Army at Pine Camp, New York, and John of the home. There are also three sisters, Mrs. Selma Bock of Wheeling, West Virginia, Mrs. Lydia Roth, also of Wheeling, and Mrs. Samuel Yaussy of Bucyrus, Ohio.
Funeral services were held at 2:00 oclock Tuesday afternoon, in charge of the Reverend H. C. Heinlein and burial was made in Mt. Vernon Methodist Church cemetery near Hannibal. Mr. Gehrig was a member of the Mt. Vernon Church.

1942X

DEATH

Eve Christman

Source: Beacon

 

On Wednesday, December 23rd, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On Wednesday, December 23rd, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 just as the Yuletide spirit was possessing the minds and hearts of both adults and children, death entered the happy country home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis E. Christman, of Lewisville, Route 1, and removed therefrom the spirit of the aged mother, Mrs. Eve Christman. Born on September 9, 1848, she was past ninety-four years of age, and until just a few weeks previous, she had been in fairly good health maintaining the spirit of self help and self reliance that characterized her long and useful life. Death followed a light stroke and as he would have wished it, she passed in her heavenly reward almost without illness of any period of helplessness, of which she was conscious.

Mrs. Christman was born on what is a now ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Christman was born on what is a now >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the George Pfalzgraf farm on Lewisville Route 1, the land having been entered by her father, George Michael Pfalzgraf who came to this country from Germany in 1832.He died in 1866. His wife, whose maiden name was Elizabeth Diehl, a sister of the late Peter Diehl, of Woodsfield, died in 1883.

Eve, who was one of a family of fourteen ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Eve, who was one of a family of fourteen >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 children, grew to womanhood on the home farm. Due somewhat to the custom of the times and to the necessity of close cooperation in home duties in so large a family, she received a limited school education, but lessons in thrift, honor, kindness, industry and faithfulness to duty were well learned and daily practiced in the Pfalzgraf home and these remained dominant in her entire life.

The other brothers and sisters are Jacob, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The other brothers and sisters are Jacob, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Rose Ann, John, Mrs. Elizabeth Eberle, Mrs. Rachael Christman, Mrs. Mary Niebch, Mrs. Magdalene Kindelberger; Lewis Pfalzgraf of Rockport, W. Va; Mrs. Barbara Ruble, Sallie, who died at the age of ten years; Mrs. Loise Koehler, Mrs. Christina Brownfield and George Pfalzgraf, the youngest and only member of the family living and who is now 86 years of age.

On December 22, 1868, Eva Pfalzgraf was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On December 22, 1868, Eva Pfalzgraf was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 united in marriage to John Christman, son of Jacob and Eva Christman, and they began housekeeping on her father-in-law's farm, now owned by George M. Christman. About five years later, they moved to the farm now owned by Lewis E. Christman, where she spent over sixty five years of an unusually active, useful life, respected and honored by friends and neighbors for miles around

And when advancing years compelled her ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> And when advancing years compelled her >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 strong body and will to depend more and more on those near to her, no daughter could have been more devoted or faithful in loving care than her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Lewis Christman, an attitude that characterized the entire household.

Mrs. Christman was confirmed in the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Christman was confirmed in the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Evangelical faith at Miltonsburg when about thirteen years of age and was a regular and faithful attendant when health permitted.

Her husband died on September 24, 1896, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Her husband died on September 24, 1896, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 leaving the responsibility and care of a large family and be it said to her credit, that she lived to realize the glory of age, that of seeing her children out in the world making good and as long as she had the power of conscious thinking, their welfare and progress, were matters of concern to her great mother heart and mind. Nor were her interests confined to her home, and many were the times hen her tireless mind and body served the needs of neighbors in sickness or distress, whether in home or field, and it was never too late or too early too hot or too cold, for her to go where she was needed or where duty <<<<<<< HEAD called her. In her passing, the family ======= called her. In her passing, the family >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and community lost a great mother, neighbor and friend; but if "To live in hearts we leave behind is not to die," she will be here for many years in the minds and hearts of those who knew and loved her for the fine woman she was.

Besides the son with whom she made her ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Besides the son with whom she made her >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 home, she is survived by one daughter, Rosa Stallings, of Summerfield Route; Philip Samuel and George, all of Woodsfield Rt. 3; John and Solomon of Quaker City Route. There are forty-seven grandchildren and seventy-three great grandchildren. Two sons, Jacob and Ben and one daughter, Mrs. Louise Ackerman, preceded their mother in death.

Mrs. Christman lived during four wars, remembering ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Christman lived during four wars, remembering >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 well the Civil Ward and the Spanish-American War. In World War 1, one son Solomon was a soldier and in the present war, several grandsons are in the service. It was her fervent hope to live to see them all home again.

Funeral services were held on Saturday, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held on Saturday, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 December 26th and were largely attended. Short services at the home were followed by final rites at Middle Church in charge of her pastor, Rev. F. A. Reigle. Interment was made in Middle Church Cemetery.

 

1943

Caroline (Lena) (Frank) Veiock -- One of Tarentum, Pa.'s best known residents, Mrs. Caroline Veiock, 76, of 609 Third avenue, died in Allegheny Valley Hospital at 8:20 Thursday evening, March 25th, 1943.  She had complained of not feeling well on Wednesday, but her illness was not considered serious until Thursday afternoon.  At 8:00 p.m. she was rushed to the hospital.

          She was born in Lewisville, Ohio on May 2, 1866, but lived in Tarentum, Pa., for the past 42 years, during which time she was very active in church and club work.  She was a member of the United Lutheran Church, Rhodes Sisterhood Dames of Malta, Imperial Council No. 68 Daughters of America, the Eleanor Mae Rebekah Lodge, and the Ladies Club of B.P.O.E. Lodge 644.

          Mrs. Veiock was held in high esteem by a host of friends, to whom her passing came as a great shock.  Possessed of a friendly, cheerful disposition, she was thoughtful and considerate of all with whom she came in contact.

          Survivors include two sons, Frank at home, and Harry, of Marion, Indiana; four daughters, Mrs. Stella Horan, at home; Mrs. Helen Laux, of Tarentum; Mrs. Ida Perry, of Massillon, O., and Mrs. Mary Evans of Harrisburg; a brother, Charles Frank, of Bellaire, and a sister, Mrs. Hattie Menkel, of Woodsfield; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

          Mrs. Veiock was the widow of the late George Veiock.

          Funeral services were conducted at the late home at 2:30 o'clock Sunday afternoon by Rev. John E. Shaughnesy, pastor of the United Lutheran Church.  Intermemt was in Prospect cemetery.

The couple was unattended.
Mrs. Taylor returned to Columbus ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Taylor returned to Columbus >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 where she is employed.
Private Taylor, who had been ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Private Taylor, who had been >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 enrolled in the University of Oregon at Corvallis, Oregon, in the A. S. T. program, has been transferred to Camp Carson, Colorado, where is not stationed.

1943
Harry M. Johnson
Spirit of Democracy
January 14, 1943
Funeral services were held on Wednesday ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held on Wednesday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 afternoon for Harry M. Johnson, 41, who was fatally injured in an automobile accident Sunday morning near New Philadelphia. Brief services were held at his late residence near Lewisville followed by additional services at The Creighton Ridge Church. Rev. Arthur Weddle officiated. The body was brought to The Gardner Funeral Home at Stafford and on Tuesday was returned to the family home.
Surviving are his wife, Nellie Johnson; one son, Lloyd of the home; and his mother, Mrs. Anna Johnson, Sycamore Valley; five sisters, Mrs. Shelia Massie, Mrs. Ethel Unger, Harrietsville; Mrs. Ella Thurla of Cambridge; Stella Hubbard of Zanesville; and Hattie Smithberger of Sycamore Valley. One ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving are his wife, Nellie Johnson; one son, Lloyd of the home; and his mother, Mrs. Anna Johnson, Sycamore Valley; five sisters, Mrs. Shelia Massie, Mrs. Ethel Unger, Harrietsville; Mrs. Ella Thurla of Cambridge; Stella Hubbard of Zanesville; and Hattie Smithberger of Sycamore Valley. One >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 brother, Clarence Johnson, of Conneaut, also survives.
Mr. Johnson was employed in the oil fields ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Johnson was employed in the oil fields >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Brunswick. He attended Creighton Ridge Church. Burial followed in the church cemetery.
 
1943
DEATH
Name: John S. Jeffries
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 28, 1943
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
John Simon Jeffries, of Avella, Pennsylvania, an oil well driller, died in Bellaire City Hospital at 11:30 p.m. Thursday, January 21, 1943, of last week of burns sustained early that day when his clothing caught fire while he was at work on a drilling operation on the Harry E. Warren farm, between Businessburg ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> John Simon Jeffries, of Avella, Pennsylvania, an oil well driller, died in Bellaire City Hospital at 11:30 p.m. Thursday, January 21, 1943, of last week of burns sustained early that day when his clothing caught fire while he was at work on a drilling operation on the Harry E. Warren farm, between Businessburg >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Jacobsburg.
Mr. Jeffries, a tool dresser, was engaged in pulling tools from the ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Jeffries, a tool dresser, was engaged in pulling tools from the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 well when the accident occurred. He is said to have stepped back into an open gas flame, used as a light which ignited his clothing. He ran from the scene and was fatally burned before a fellow workman would reach him. The burns extended over a major portion of the body.
Deceased was a native of Belmont County. He leaves his wife, the former Miss Opal Willison, of Woodsfield; his mother, Mrs. Loretta Jeffries of Neffs; ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Deceased was a native of Belmont County. He leaves his wife, the former Miss Opal Willison, of Woodsfield; his mother, Mrs. Loretta Jeffries of Neffs; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two sisters, Mrs. Jeanette McHendry of Neffs and Mrs. Anna Norris of Belmont, and two brothers, Taylor and Clayton Jeffries, both of Neffs.
The body was brought to the home of Orville Willison at Woodsfield, Saturday. Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at 2 oclock at the Woodsfield Church of Christ , with the Reverend Charles Rock officiating. Burial was made in the Neuhart Ridge ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The body was brought to the home of Orville Willison at Woodsfield, Saturday. Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at 2 o clock at the Woodsfield Church of Christ , with the Reverend Charles Rock officiating. Burial was made in the Neuhart Ridge >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 cemetery.
Mr. Jeffries was about 41 years of age.

Mrs. Ophelia Doherty, of Woodsfield, is a sister-in-law of the deceased.
Mr. Doherty was a member of the Methodist Church and was secretary of the W. O. W. Lodge. He was well known among the older citizens of Woodsfield and was held in high esteem. Funeral services and burial were in Pueblo.

1943
 
-- One of Tarentum, Pa.'s best known residents, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> -- One of Tarentum, Pa.'s best known residents, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Caroline Veiock, 76, of 609 Third avenue, died in Allegheny Valley Hospital at 8:20 Thursday evening, March 25th, 1943.  She had complained of not feeling well on Wednesday, but her illness was not considered serious until Thursday afternoon.  At 8:00 p.m. she was rushed to the hospital.
            She was born in Lewisville, Ohio on May 2, 1866, but lived in Tarentum, Pa., for the past 42 years, during which time she was very active in church and club work.  She was a member of the United Lutheran Church, Rhodes Sisterhood Dames of Malta, Imperial Council No. 68 Daughters of America, the Eleanor Mae Rebekah Lodge, and the Ladies Club of B.P.O.E. Lodge 644.
            Mrs. Veiock was held in high esteem by a host of friends, to whom her passing came as a great shock.  Possessed of a friendly, cheerful disposition, she was thoughtful and considerate of all with whom she came in contact.
            Survivors include two sons, Frank at home, and Harry, of Marion, Indiana; four daughters, Mrs. Stella Horan, at home; Mrs. Helen Laux, of Tarentum; Mrs. Ida Perry, of Massillon, O., and Mrs. Mary Evans of Harrisburg; a brother, Charles Frank, of Bellaire, and a sister, Mrs. Hattie Menkel, of Woodsfield; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.
            Mrs. Veiock was the widow of the late George Veiock.
            Funeral services were conducted at the late home at 2:30 o'clock Sunday afternoon by Rev. John E. Shaughnesy, pastor of the United Lutheran Church.  Interment was in Prospect cemetery.
 

 

June 17, 1943

BIRTH

Son

Source: The Spirit of Democracy

Delmas Rodney BettsX

A son was born Wednesday, June 9th ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> A son was born Wednesday, June 9th >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to Mr. and Mrs. Elbert Betts, of Lewisville Rt. 2. 1943X
Floyd Harper:
Floyd Harper Dies In Japanese Camp
June 24, 1943
Royden Harper ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>
Royden Harper >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Canton has been notified by The War Department that his son, Pvt. Floyd Harper died in a Japanese prison in The Philippines on June 11. The telegram was recieved by Mr. Harper , Saturday, June 19th.
Pvt. Harper ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Pvt. Harper >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was inducted into the Army in Detroit, Michigan in April 1941 and was first sent to Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland. He was later transferred to The Savannah Air Base in Georgia and then sent to Corregidor in The Philippines. The last word the family had from him directly was a telegram on Christmas Day in 1941.
Pvt. Harper ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Pvt. Harper >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born near Malaga on September 22, 1914, the son of Roydon Harper and the late Nina Stalder Harper. His mother preceded him in death on August 26,1928, as did a sister, Lucille in February 1937.
He was a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 member of The Evangelical and Reformed Church in Louisville, Stark County, having been confirmed at the age of 12 years. He graduated from The Lewisville High School in Monroe County in the class of 1933. He was employed in Detroit several years before being inducted into The Army.
In addition ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In addition >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to his father, he is survived by two brothers who are in the armed forces: Cpl. Virgil Harper of Camp Forest, Tennessee and Pfc. Ray Harper who is on manuevers in Louisiana, and two sisters, Mrs. Frances Heft, the former Miss Vivian Harper, of Lewisville and Miss Phyllis Harper of Canton. Two grandmothers also survive, Mrs. James Harper of near Malaga and Mrs. Louise Stalder of Miltonsburg.
 
1943
DEATH
Name:Mrs. Anna K. Ludwig, nee Hehr
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Issue: Woodsfield, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio, June 1943
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
Mrs. Anna K. Ludwig, nee Hehr, was ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Anna K. Ludwig, nee Hehr, was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 born in Summit township, Monroe County, Ohio, June 22, 1874 and died suddenly June 23, 1943 of a heart ailment while visiting a brother, Edward Hehr, in Wheeling, West Virginia. She had attained the age of 69 years and one day.
Mrs. Ludwig was baptized and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Ludwig was baptized and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 confirmed in the Faith of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, of which she remained a consistent member until death.
On February 14, 1898, she was untied ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On February 14, 1898, she was untied >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in marriage with John S. Ludwig and to this union, two children were born: Mrs. Helen Egger, of Akron, Ohio, and Gilbert J. Ludwig, of Woodsfield.
Surviving are her two children; five ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Surviving are her two children; five >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 grandchildren; three sisters, Mrs. Elizabeth Forbes and Mrs. Freda Larkin of Pittsburg, Pennsylvania; Mrs. Charley Ihlenfeld of Wheeling; four brothers, William Hehr of Lewisville; Edward and Ben Hehr of Wheeling, and John Hehr of Canton, Ohio.
Short services were held in the home ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Short services were held in the home >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Gilbert J. Ludwig at 2:00 p.m. and final rites at 2:30 p.m. at the Evangelical and Reformed Church, Woodsfield, on Saturday, June 26th, with her pastor, Reverend John H. Hose, officiating. Burial was made in Oaklawn cemetery, Woodsfield.
We rejoice alike that her life was full of good deeds.
Her soul to him who gave it rose,
God ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Her soul to him who gave it rose,
God >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 called it to its long repose,
Eternal Rest.
Although our Mothers sun is set,
Her light shall linger round us yet.
Bright, radiant blest.
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Eternal Rest.
Although our Mother s sun is set,
Her light shall linger round us yet.
Bright, radiant blest.

1943
Minnie (Griffin) English
Mrs. Minnie English Dies Friday
July 8, 1943
Mrs. Minnie Griffin English, 56 , died here Friday afternoon at the home of her daughter, Mrs. R. H. Meek of Eastern Avenue. Death followed a brief illness of heart trouble.
Brief funeral services were held Monday at 1:30 p.m. at the Meek home, with additional rites at The Church of Christ with J. V. A. Traylor officiating. Burial was made in Oaklawn Cemetery, with The Galbraith Funeral Home in charge.
Born at Rinard Mills, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Griffin, the deceased is survived by six children; Mrs. Meek with whom she resided; Mrs. Warren Smith of Graysville; Mrs. Paul Drum of Detroit, Michigan; Mrs. Bernard Forshey of Lower Salem; George and Claude English of Canton; five brothers; Ellsworth, Marion and Russell Griffen of Rinard Mills, Emmett of Friendly, West Virginia and Otis of Holidays Cove, W. Va..; also two sisters, Mrs. Al Drum of Senecaville, Ohio and Mrs. Everett Smith of ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>July 8, 1943
Mrs. Minnie Griffin English, 56 , died here Friday afternoon at the home of her daughter, Mrs. R. H. Meek of Eastern Avenue. Death followed a brief illness of heart trouble.
Brief funeral services were held Monday at 1:30 p.m. at the Meek home, with additional rites at The Church of Christ with J. V. A. Traylor officiating. Burial was made in Oaklawn Cemetery, with The Galbraith Funeral Home in charge.
Born at Rinard Mills, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Griffin, the deceased is survived by six children; Mrs. Meek with whom she resided; Mrs. Warren Smith of Graysville; Mrs. Paul Drum of Detroit, Michigan; Mrs. Bernard Forshey of Lower Salem; George and Claude English of Canton; five brothers; Ellsworth, Marion and Russell Griffen of Rinard Mills, Emmett of Friendly, West Virginia and Otis of Holidays Cove, W. Va..; also two sisters, Mrs. Al Drum of Senecaville, Ohio and Mrs. Everett Smith of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Whipple, Ohio. One sister, Mrs. Lewis Lallathin, preceded her in death, and four children preceded their mother in death.
When we say ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> When we say >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 reverently "She was a good mother, neighbor and friend" in reference to a loved one who has passed to The Great Beyond, we pay high tribute to that personality. That is what those who knew her best and enjoyed her friendship say of Mrs. English. She was loyal and steadfast and the interests of her family and faithfulness to her church were first in her consideration.
The bereaved ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The bereaved >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 family have the sympathy of many friends in their loss of a devoted mother.

July, 29, 1943

Surviving are Mrs. Viola Hines of Woodsfield, a sister; three children, Crawford of El Dorado, with whom Mr. Cronin had made his home for the past three years; Steward of Oklahoma; Mrs. Arthur Staudt of Akron, and several ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving are Mrs. Viola Hines of Woodsfield, a sister; three children, Crawford of El Dorado, with whom Mr. Cronin had made his home for the past three years; Steward of Oklahoma; Mrs. Arthur Staudt of Akron, and several >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 grandchildren.

Later, upon going to Texas, he was employed by The Pure Oil CoMpant in leasing and right-of-way work.
He was 76 years old.

Burial will be at the cemetery of St. John's ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Lena Ackerman

Funeral services will be held Friday morning at 10 o'clock at the home in charge of Rev. Walter Togler, pastor of the Evangelical and Reformed Church, Woodsfield. Burial will be at the cemetery of St. John's >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Church, Summit township.
Mrs. Ackerman was born in Monroefield, the daughter ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Ackerman was born in Monroefield, the daughter >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Philip and Rosina Pfalzgraf Christman.
