Wednesday, August 25, 1943, p. 3]
 
Aug. 29, 1943
Elza Lumbatis
Elza Lumbatis, of Lewisville, son of Jacob and Elizabeth Colvin Lumbatis, was born near St. Marys, West Va., on July 31, 1882. he passed away on August 29, 1943 at Marietta Osteopathic Hospital at the age of 61 years and 29 days. He ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Elza Lumbatis, of Lewisville, son of Jacob and Elizabeth Colvin Lumbatis, was born near St. Mary s, West Va., on July 31, 1882. he passed away on August 29, 1943 at Marietta Osteopathic Hospital at the age of 61 years and 29 days. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was one of the family of nine children, the family moving to Ohio in the Autumn of 1903.
He was united in matrimony with Miss ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> He was united in matrimony with Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Alice Emmaline Feiock, August 20, 1905, who survives him. To this happy union were born nine children: Mrs. Mildred Denbow, of Greentown, Ohio; Charles Lumbatis, of Lewisville; Mrs. Sylvia Barendt, of Williamsport, Pa.: Miss Ruby Lumbatis, of Lewisville; Ward Lumbatis, of Lewisville; Mrs. Mary Weber, of Greentown; Pfc. Lewis Lumbatis, of the Army Air Corps, Smyrna, Tenn; Miss Ruth Lumbatis, of Akron, and Lloyd Dale Lumbatis, of North Canton. There are nine grandsons and four granddaughters, the two oldest grandsons serving with the armed forces of the United States.
Mr. Lumbatis was preceded in death ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Lumbatis was preceded in death >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by his mother and father, and is survived by all his brothers and sisters, those being Mrs. Jennie Campbell, Mrs. Aley Bowman and Ray Lumbatis, of Zanesville; John Lumbatis, Mrs. Emma Hanson, and Arthur Lumbatis, of Lewisville; Mrs. Manda Leasure, of Cleveland, and Mrs. Goldia Bruce, of Lorain.
Mr. Lumbatis had lived and worked in the vicinity of Lewisville the past forty years. He had always been a firm believer in the constructive ways of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Lumbatis had lived and worked in the vicinity of Lewisville the past forty years. He had always been a firm believer in the constructive ways of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 live, his interest lying in his family and work. For the past several years he had seen the fulfillment of many of his desires. For many weeks he had expressed a readiness and desire to go on, realizing that he had had a full and complete life. He was greatly loved by his family and had many friends. While we will miss him greatly, we would not wish to deprive him of the privilege and <<<<<<< HEAD joy of entering his Fathers House.
======= joy of entering his Father s House. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

1943
JAMES W. CAIN
 
[Source: Wheeling News Register, Friday, September 3, 1943]
 
James W. Cain Rites Saturday
 
Services will be held Saturday morning at 9 o'clock at the Olszta funeral home for James W. Cain, veteran of World War I, who died Thursday in the Veterans hospital at Aspinwall, Pa. Interment will follow in the Cain cemetery at Clarington, Ohio.
 
The family residence is at 4260 Franklin street, Bellaire, O.
 
Mr. Cain was a charter member of Blake Brothers Post of the American Legion in Benwood.
 
Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Cain, two sons, Kenneth Robert Cain at home, and Arlington E. Cain with the U. S. Navy; one daughter, Miss Regina Cain, Bellaire, O.; four sisters, Mrs. Frank DeBolt, Wheeling; Mrs. Howard Dunfee, Bellaire, O.; Mrs. Margaret Wright, Bellaire, O., and Mrs. Eugene Grossenback, Woodsfield, O.; his father, Isaac Cain, Clarington, O.; his grandfather, James W. Cain, Clarington, O.

Cline, aged 88 years, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Emery >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Edwards at Mingo Junction, on Saturday morning, September 4. The body was brought to her late home at Low Gap and remained there until Tuesday afternoon when funeral services were held at The Christian Union Church. Burial was made in the church cemetery in charge of Galbraith Funeral Home of Woodsfield.
Mrs. Cline is survived by four daughters, Mrs. Edwards in whose home she died, Mrs. James Gray of Woodsfield, Mrs. Barnett Williamson of Okmulgee, Okla., and Mrs. Everett Smith of Rinard Mills, and two sons, Luther Cline of Plainview and John ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Cline is survived by four daughters, Mrs. Edwards in whose home she died, Mrs. James Gray of Woodsfield, Mrs. Barnett Williamson of Okmulgee, Okla., and Mrs. Everett Smith of Rinard Mills, and two sons, Luther Cline of Plainview and John >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cline of Low Gap. Her husband died seven years ago.

Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Jacob ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Jacob >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Walter, 81, one of the oldest merchants in Monroe count, Ohio, and for 50 years engaged in business in the Morton community near Sardis, Ohio, died Tuesday evening, October 25, 1943.
He was the son of the late Jacob and Ann Ritz Walter and a lifelong member of the St. Johns Methodist Church.
Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> He was the son of the late Jacob and Ann Ritz Walter and a lifelong member of the St. John s Methodist Church.

Walter of Warwood; Jacob and Hugh Walter of Woodsfield; four brothers, John and Robert Walter of Rittman; William Walter of Sardis and Edward Walter of Martins Ferry; three sisters, Mrs. Carrie Merschrod, Wheeling, West Virginia; Mrs. Mary Tomi of Salem, Ohio and Mrs. Ida Hurd of Newton Falls, Ohio; 18 grandchildren and four great grandchildren. A son Eugene, and a daughter, Lula, preceded him in death a number of years ago while his wife died on April 14 of this year. Funeral <<<<<<< HEAD services will be held at his home on Friday afternoon at 2 oclock. Reverend D. E. Dangel of the Methodist Church and the Reverend John Sutz of Mt. Zion Evangelical and Reformed Church will officiate. Burial will be made in the Salem Church cemetery, Salem, by the Rush funeral home.

1943X
DEATH
Name: Catherine Kilburn, nee Kahrig
Source: Newspaper clipping
November 1943
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Catherine Kahrig Kilburn,was born July 11, 1873 and after a several months illness passed away at her home near ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Catherine Kahrig Kilburn,was born July 11, 1873 and after a several months illness passed away at her home near >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Lewisville, Ohio on the morning of November 2, 1943, being at the time of her passing 70 years, 4 months and 18 days of age.
On March 27, 1894, she was united in marriage with Henry Kilburn, and to this union three children were born: Homer, Mrs. Anna Claus and Charles, all of the vicinity of Lewisville. In addition to the bereaved husband and three children, she leaves to morn her departure, eight grandchildren, three of whom are in the service of the United States Army; Bernard and Floyd Claus, and Clyde Kilburn; two great grandchildren; two sisters, Mrs. Mary Kilburn, of Lewisville, and Mrs. Freda Boldt, of Columbus, Ohio; two brothers, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On March 27, 1894, she was united in marriage with Henry Kilburn, and to this union three children were born: Homer, Mrs. Anna Claus and Charles, all of the vicinity of Lewisville. In addition to the bereaved husband and three children, she leaves to morn her departure, eight grandchildren, three of whom are in the service of the United States Army; Bernard and Floyd Claus, and Clyde Kilburn; two great grandchildren; two sisters, Mrs. Mary Kilburn, of Lewisville, and Mrs. Freda Boldt, of Columbus, Ohio; two brothers, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Philip Kahrig, of Lewisville and Fred Kahrig, of Woodsfield, Ohio, besides several nieces and nephews and a host of relatives, friends and neighbors.
At an early age she was confirmed at St. Johns Evangelical and Reformed Church of Summit township, Monroe County, near Lewisville and remained a faithful member through her entire life. She was a woman who loved her home and was very devoted to her family. She will live on in the minds of her loved ones as they remember her kind words and deeds throughout the years.
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> At an early age she was confirmed at St. John s Evangelical and Reformed Church of Summit township, Monroe County, near Lewisville and remained a faithful member through her entire life. She was a woman who loved her home and was very devoted to her family. She will live on in the minds of her loved ones as they remember her kind words and deeds throughout the years. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

December 30, 1943

January 3, 1944X

MARRIAGE

Hamilton - Christman

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

The Walter Trogler read the double ring ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The Walter Trogler read the double ring >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 ceremony on Christmas Day which united in marriage Freda Katherine Christman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. P. Christman of Woodsfield and Mr. Homer Okey Hamilton, son of Sylvester Hamilton of near Woodsfield. The wedding was solemnized in the parsonage of the St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church at 10:30 o'clock in the morning.

The bride wore a pastel wool dress with ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The bride wore a pastel wool dress with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 which she used wine accessories. The couple was unattended.

On Sunday a wedding dinner was served for ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On Sunday a wedding dinner was served for >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the bride and groom at the home of the bride's brother, Dr. N. A. Christman and Mrs. Christman at their home on Eastern Avenue. A beautifully decorated three-tier wedding cake topped by a miniature bride and groom centered the dinner table.

Covers were laid for the following: Mr. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Covers were laid for the following: Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Mrs. L. P. Christman, parents of the bride, Sylvester Hamilton, father of the groom, Walter, Clayton and John Christman, Miss Mary Hamilton, Edward Hamilton, the guests of honor; Mr. and Mrs. Homer Hamilton and Dr. and Mrs. Christman and daughter Charlotte.

The newlyweds have gone to Columbus where ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The newlyweds have gone to Columbus where >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 they will reside.

1944
DEATH
Name: Henry Philip Claus
Source: Newspaper clipping 1944
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 1944 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
Henry Philip Claus, departed this ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Henry Philip Claus, departed this >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 life Monday, March 20, 1944, at his home near Middle Church at the age of 73 years, 10 months, and 20 days. Although his death was sudden, he had been in failing health since undergoing operation a year ago.
He was born May 1, 1870, in Malaga Township, and was the son of the late Justus and Carolina Schmidt Claus. He was confirmed at the St. Johns Evangelical and Reformed Church in Summit township where he ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was born May 1, 1870, in Malaga Township, and was the son of the late Justus and Carolina Schmidt Claus. He was confirmed at the St. John s Evangelical and Reformed Church in Summit township where he >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 remained a faithful member until his death. He was united in marriage on January 30, 1894 with Miss Minnie Brubach. He spent his entire life in this community, where he had made a host of lifelong friends, who in addition to his family and relatives will mourn his passing.
Surviving ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Claus are his wife, three sons: Everett Claus, of Lewisville; Walter Claus, of Akron; Emil Claus, of Bucyrus; one daughter, Mrs. Hulda McDonough, of Akron; eleven grandchildren, two great grandchildren, two sisters; Mrs. Ann Friday, of Columbus; Mrs. Elizabeth Wilhelm, of Parkersburg, W. Va., and three brothers: Herman Claus and Clarence Claus, of Hornick, Iowa, and Edward Claus, of Pittsburgh, Pa. Two sisters, Mrs. Louise Scheurr, of Pittsburg, Pa., and Mrs. Clara Theiss, of Lower Salem, Ohio, and one brother, Jacob Claus, of Hornick, Iowa, preceded him in death.
Just ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Just >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 recently Mr. and Mrs. Claus together with the family observed their golden wedding anniversary.
Here at last, and over yonder
Just within the pearly gates
Watching still for loved ones coming ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Here at last, and over yonder
Just within the pearly gates
Watching still for loved ones coming >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 --
Now our father peacefully waits.
When we, too, shall cross the river,
And on earth no longer roam,
May we reunite together
Safe at last, in that bright home.

And on earth no longer roam,

1944XXXXX

Herbert Busche
Herbert Busche Is Killed in Accident
June 1, 1944
Herbert Busche,33, was instantly killed in ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'>
Herbert Busche,33, was instantly killed in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 an automobile accident on The Clifford Ring Hill near Low Gap about eleven o'clock Sunday night. It is believed that a broken axle caused the car to turn over a steep embankment while going down the hill.
Mr. and Mrs. Busche, who live at Gypsum, Ohio, had come to Monroe County Sunday morning to spend their vacation with relatives. They had spent the day with Mr. and Mrs. Roy Cline and were on their way to the home of ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. Busche, who live at Gypsum, Ohio, had come to Monroe County Sunday morning to spend their vacation with relatives. They had spent the day with Mr. and Mrs. Roy Cline and were on their way to the home of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Busche's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dan Dillon, when the accident happened.
In the car with Mr. and Mrs. Busche were Mr. and Mrs. Dan Dillon and their daughter, Miss Carrie Dillon. Miss Dillon sustained a broken leg, and Mrs Dillon, serious injuries. Both were taken ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> In the car with Mr. and Mrs. Busche were Mr. and Mrs. Dan Dillon and their daughter, Miss Carrie Dillon. Miss Dillon sustained a broken leg, and Mrs Dillon, serious injuries. Both were taken >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to Marietta Memorial Hospital. Mr. Dillon recieved chest and leg injuries. Mrs. Busche was not seriously injured.
Surviving Mr. Busche are his wife, Mrs. Gladys Dillon Busche; his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. Busche of New Matamoras, Route 2; one sister, Mrs. Bernadine Hensel of New Matamoras Rt.2; and two brothers, of the home; and Ralph ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving Mr. Busche are his wife, Mrs. Gladys Dillon Busche; his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. Busche of New Matamoras, Route 2; one sister, Mrs. Bernadine Hensel of New Matamoras Rt.2; and two brothers, of the home; and Ralph >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Busche, S-2c of Gulfport,Miss.

DEATH

John Eberle

Source: The Spirit of Democracy

John Eberle, 83 died at his home on ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'>

John Eberle, 83 died at his home on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Beallsville Route 3, on Thursday evening, June 1st as the result of a stroke suffered about two weeks ago.

Funeral services were held Sunday ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held Sunday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 afternoon in Asbury Chapel in charge of Rev. Robert Ferguson of the Beallsville Methodist Church. Burial was made in the Church Cemetery by Campbell and Blowers of Beallsville.

Mr. Eberle is survived by two brothers and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Eberle is survived by two brothers and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 three sisters: Louis of North Woodbury, Ohio and George of Scottdale, Pa., Mrs. John Eriewine of Marion, Indiana, Mrs. J. H. Gillespie of New Kensington, Pa. and Mrs. E. C. Beall of Zanesville.

Mr. Eberle was unmarried and lived alone. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Eberle was unmarried and lived alone. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Recently he was stricken with paralysis which resulted in his death.

He was of happy disposition hospitable and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was of happy disposition hospitable and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 friendly always self reliant and industrious and was well known in eastern Monroe County. In his death Adams Township loses one of the oldest and best citizen.

 

1944
Clair Devore
James Ullman
Two Boys Drown Sunday Near Stafford
June 8, 1944
Clair Devore Loses Life In Attempt To Rescue James Ullman:
A double drowning shocked the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'>
A double drowning shocked the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Stafford-Lewisville communities Sunday afternoon when two fine young men lost their lives in Clearfork Creek, about two miles southeast of Stafford. They were James Henry Ullman, who would have been 22 years of age on June 29 and Clair Devore who was 17 years old last November 6. Devore, a fairly good swimmer was in the water, which in places was 12 to 15 feet deep. He cautioned his friend not to come out too far and Ullman replied that he would wade close <<<<<<< HEAD to the bank. As he was wading he ======= to the bank. As he was wading he >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 suddenly disappeared, apparently stepping into a deep hole. Devore went to aid him and both were drowned.
This is according to three ten year old ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> This is according to three ten year old >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 boys, Donald and Charles Hines and Junior Robbins who were sitting on the bank. They summoned help and Leonard Hines and William Hawkins arrived almost immediately and Ullman was taken out of the water in about 15 minutes, but he couldn't be saved while Devore was in the water about 45 minutes.
Devore was graduated this year from the Lewisville High School and had done excellent work. He had won a four-year scholarship in college of agriculture at Ohio State University. He is survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Delbert Devore of near Lewisville; one brother Carl who is with the armed forces in England and Glen of the home ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Devore was graduated this year from the Lewisville High School and had done excellent work. He had won a four-year scholarship in college of agriculture at Ohio State University. He is survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Delbert Devore of near Lewisville; one brother Carl who is with the armed forces in England and Glen of the home >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and four sisters, Mrs. Chester Deeker, Geraldine, Eileen and Joan of the home.
Ullman is survived by his father, Walter Ullman and one sister. Mrs. Dorothy Kestner of Port Clinton. His only brother, Lester who preceded him death in Africa last September. James had passed his pre-induction examination and was waiting to be called for service. He was graduated from the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Ullman is survived by his father, Walter Ullman and one sister. Mrs. Dorothy Kestner of Port Clinton. His only brother, Lester who preceded him death in Africa last September. James had passed his pre-induction examination and was waiting to be called for service. He was graduated from the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Lewisville High School.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

August 3, 1944X

MARRIAGEXXXXX

Christman-Beardmore

Source: Monroe County Republican

 

Wednesday ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Wednesday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 evening, June 21, at 8:00 o'clock, Miss Marie Beardmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Beardmore, of Malaga, and Cpl. Paul Christman of Lewisville, were united in marriage at St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church, Woodsfield by Rev. Walter Trogler. The impressive double bring ceremony was used.

Miss Beryl Christman, a sister of the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Beryl Christman, a sister of the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 bridegroom, played a program of organ nupital numbers, Miss Beulah Spar, of Columbus sang beautifully "At Dawning"

The bride who advanced to the altar on the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The bride who advanced to the altar on the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 arm of her brother Leland, was preceded by Misses Nada and Geneva Saffeil. The bride was met by Cpl. Christman and his best man, Edison Beardmore, the bride's brother, who with the officiating clergyman, took their places from a side entrance.

The ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 bridal gown of white marquisette over satin was fashioned with a fitted lace bodice and long sleeves. The full skirt fell into a short train. The veil of illusion was shoulder length fastened to a pearl beaded tiara. The bride carried a bouquet of roses, carnations and baby breath.

Miss Nada Saffeil wore a poudre blue floor ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Nada Saffeil wore a poudre blue floor >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 length dress of marquisette. A corsage completed her costume.

Miss Geneva Saffeil appeared in a pink ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Geneva Saffeil appeared in a pink >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 taffeta gown with a corsage worn at the shoulder.

After the ceremony Cpl. and Mrs. Christman ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> After the ceremony Cpl. and Mrs. Christman >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 took their places at the back of the auditorium to greet and receive congratulations.

Immediately following an informal ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Immediately following an informal >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 reception was held at the home of the bride's parents for member of the immediate families.

Mrs. Christman was graduated from ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Christman was graduated from >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Beallsville High School, attended Bliss College, Columbus and is now employed in the office of David Davies Meat Packing, Inc., Columbus where she will continue her work for the present.

Cpl. Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Cpl. Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 L. Christman is a graduate of Lewisville High School and attended Ohio University at Athens. Previous to his induction into the services, he was a teacher in the Wayne County Schools. He is now stationed at Camp Ellis, Illinois, where he is a projectionist, in a War Department theater.

 

1944

Mary Neuhart Latta, nee Neuhart

Source:  MONROE CO., OH OBITUARIES, Vol. 2 , page 37

Mrs. Mary Newhart Latta, 72, mother of Dr. R.H. Latta of Graysville, died Friday evening at her home in Graysville following an illness of several weeks.

Mrs. Latta had spent her entire life at Graysville and in Monroe Co.  Her husband, Dr. A.F. Latta, died some years ago.  Survivors are her son, Dr. R. H. Latta; and two brothers, Frank Newhart & Willis Newhart of Batesville.

Funeral services were held at the home in Graysville Monday afternoon at 1:00 in charge of Minister J.V.A. Traylor of the Church of Christ, of which she was a member.  Internment was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

Besides her church affiliation, Mrs. Latta was a member of the Order of Eastern Star, of Woodsfield.  They conducted the ritualistic service at the cemetery, commemorating the virtues of their departed sister.

Mrs. Latta was loved and highly respected in her home community.  Endowed by nature with a fine personality, and motivated by a fine Christian spirit, she won and kept the friendship and good will of a wide acquaintance.  Her passing to her heavenly reward is mourned by scores of friends beyond the family circle."  (11 August 1944)

 

1944
DOTY, James Ery DOTY, James Ery>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 style='font-family:Helvetica;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language: JA'>

James Doty 72, passed away Tuesday, 4:00 pm at his home in Woodsfield, Ohio. He was the father of Minnie Bergund, Madge Doty, Corilda Brown, Norman, Chester, Richard, James, & Jean Doty. He was preceded in death by his wife Amanda J.William's(Doty) Aug. 16, 1926, and two sons Ralph E.died Feb. 1931 & George L. Doty who died Feb. 1944. and one daughter Garnet E. Doty (Hall) in Sept. 1940.

1945
John W. Feiock
Dies at Hebron
Published January 11, 1945
Many friends ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Published January 11, 1945
Many friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in Monroe County regretted last week to learn of the death of John. W. Feiock, 78 , at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Marion Robinson at Hebron. He had been in failing health the past year and confined to his bed for several weeks prior to his death, which occurred Thursday evening, Jan. 4.
Mr. Feiock ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Feiock >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born Sept. 30, 1866 in Lewisville, and was a son of George and Katherine (Butt) Feiock. He grew to manhood in that community and for a number of years operated a hotel in Lewisville during the oil boom period and before the day of automobile travel. His pleasing personality and congeniality made many friends and he was elected sheriff of Monroe County serving from 1910 to 1914. He also served as deputy fire marshall of ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He also served as deputy fire marshall of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Monroe, Belmont and Washington counties by appointment when James M. Cox was governor.
Twenty-two ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Twenty-two >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 years ago he moved to Hebron. He was always an ardent Democrat, but in 1924 he was elected Mayor of Hebron, serving two terms and was again elected in 1943. In the interim he served as a justice of the peace.
Kindness, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Kindness, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 justice and fairness in his relations with people were outstanding characteristics of his personality, always. He was a member of St. Peter's Evangelical & Reformed Church in Lewisville and also of Hebron Lodge F. & A.M.
Besides his widow, Louisa (Friday) Feiock, he is survived by one daughter, Eunice, Mrs. Marion Robinson; a grandson, Paul Robinson, in The U.S. Navy. and one brother Charles E. Feiock, of Lewisville.
Funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Besides his widow, Louisa (Friday) Feiock, he is survived by one daughter, Eunice, Mrs. Marion Robinson; a grandson, Paul Robinson, in The U.S. Navy. and one brother Charles E. Feiock, of Lewisville.
Funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 services were held at the home, Saturday afternoon with Rev. Weed officiating. Final rites were held at St. Peter's Church at Lewisville, Sunday afternoon, in charge of the pastor, Rev. Walter Trogler. Interment was in Friendship Cemetery at Lewisville.
The near ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The near >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 relatives appreciate sincerely the sympathy extended and the many kindnesses of friends and neighbors.
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
1945X
DEATH
Name: George Pfalzgraf
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., Jan. 18, 1945
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
George Pfalzgraf, 88, died at his home on Lewisville Route 1, Sunday noon, January 14, 1945 following several days illness. Funeral services were held at his home Wednesday afternoon in charge of Reverend Walter M. Trogler of St. Pauls Evangelical and Reformed ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> George Pfalzgraf, 88, died at his home on Lewisville Route 1, Sunday noon, January 14, 1945 following several days illness. Funeral services were held at his home Wednesday afternoon in charge of Reverend Walter M. Trogler of St. Paul s Evangelical and Reformed >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Church, Woodsfield, and burial was made in Middle Church cemetery by the Gardner Funeral Home, of Stafford.
Mr. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Pfalzgraf is survived by one son, Ben Pfalzgraf, of the home, and three daughters, Mrs. Philip Kahrig, Mrs. Elmer Bintz, and Mrs. Wesley Bintz, all of Lewisville Route 1. His wife, Sophia Kilburn Pfalzgraf died several years ago, and two daughters also preceded him in death: Mrs. Annie Bintz and Miss Tillie Pfalzgraf.
George Pfalzgraf was the youngest of a family of 14 children and was the last of his family. He died on the farm which his father, George Michael Pfalzgraf, entered when he came to this country from Germany ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> George Pfalzgraf was the youngest of a family of 14 children and was the last of his family. He died on the farm which his father, George Michael Pfalzgraf, entered when he came to this country from Germany >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in 1832. His father died in 1866 and his mother whose maiden name was Elizabeth Diehl of Woodsfield, died in 1883. The other 13 children n of Michael and Elizabeth Pfalzgraf were: Jacob, Rose Ann, John, Mrs. Elizabeth Eberle, Mrs. Rachel Christman, Mrs. Mary Niebch, Mrs. Magdalene Kindelberger, Lewis Pfalzgraf of Rockport, W. Va., Mrs. Barbara Ruble, Sallie, who died at the age of ten, Mrs. Louise Koehler, Mrs. Christina Brownfield, and Mrs. Eve Christman.
Mr. Pfalzgrafs entire life was characterized by self-reliance, thrift and industry, and he was one of the best known citizens in western Monroe County. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Pfalzgraf s entire life was characterized by self-reliance, thrift and industry, and he was one of the best known citizens in western Monroe County. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 
1945
William E. Dietrich
William E. Dietrich Dies At Hannibal
January 19, 1945
Saturday afternoon, Monroe County, lost one of her best known citizens in the person of William F. Dietrich, whose death occurred at his home near Hannibal at 4 ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>
Saturday afternoon, Monroe County, lost one of her best known citizens in the person of William F. Dietrich, whose death occurred at his home near Hannibal at 4 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 o'clock. He retired Friday evening apparently as usual but became ill in the night, having suffered a cerebral hemorrhage. A physician was summoned but the strong physique that had served an active mind for nearly 79 years had yielded to the inevitable.
Mr. Dietrich was born April 28, 1866, being ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Dietrich was born April 28, 1866, being >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 one of a family of twelve children born to the late John and Sarah Dietrich, who moved from a farm near Welcome, W.Va. to the present farm on "Buckhill Bottom" when Mr. Dietrich was six years old. Here he spent his boyhood, received the customary rural school education and on February 27, 1890, he was united in marriage to Miss Sarah J. Cline. To this same home he brought his bride and here they reared their family, made a good living and a little more, supported schools and churches, and in short exemplified The American way of life at its best.
Both parents lived to realize the glory of ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Both parents lived to realize the glory of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 age, that of seeing their children out in the world making good, and took a just pride therein.
Recognized by reason of character, ability ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Recognized by reason of character, ability >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and personality, Mr. Dietrich served his community in various capacities. Not only was he a faithful member of The Methodist Church at Hannibal, but he served on the church board for many years, also as member of the township school board and as township trustee, he was instrumental in securing
better school facilities and road improvement in his community. From 1912 to 1916 he served as county commissioner ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 1912 to 1916 he served as county commissioner >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and at the time of his death was a member of the county board of education, and had been for nine years. In both larger spheres he was an advocate of improvement and progress.
Mr. and Mrs. Dietrich took life in its ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. Dietrich took life in its >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 stride, including the solicitude of those in military service of two wars. His son, Donald C. Dietrich, now treasurer and general manager of The Wheeling Wholesale Grocery Co. and member of Wheeling city council was a member of the first contingent of nine men to go to Camp Sherman in World War 1. They left for Camp Sherman on Sept. 7, 1917.
Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 at The Rush Funeral Home in Clarington in charge of his pastor, Rev. Kenneth Evans, and were largely attended. Sympathy and esteem of friends were evidenced by many floral offerings from individuals and organizations.
Interment was made in the family lot in The ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Interment was made in the family lot in The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Buckhill Cemetery, near the late residence.
Up to the day of his death, Mr. Dietrich's ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Up to the day of his death, Mr. Dietrich's >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 habitual energy, self-reliance and desire to be useful characterized his daily life. He refused to retire in the usual sense of the word, and was carrying a farm program worthy the effort of a man many years his junior.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon
IWoodsfield, Ohio, February 1, 1945
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ackerman, of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. and Mrs. Francis Ackerman, of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Eastern avenue, are the parents of an 8 1/2 lb. son, named Frederick Paulus Ackerman, born Friday evening, January 26th. Mrs. Ackerman is the former Miss Virginia Rosenlieb. The grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ackerman, of Woodsfield, and Mrs. Mary Rosenlieb, of Canton, Ohio. Abe Longdon, of Zanesville, Ohio, is the great grandfather.
 

February 5, 1945X

DEATH

Paul E. Pfalzgraf

Source: Beacon

 

Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Pfalzgraf of Cameron, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Pfalzgraf of Cameron, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 have received word that their son, Lt. Paul E. Pfalzgraf, 23, was killed in an airplane crash to Italy January 15th. He was a navigator on a B-24 bomber.

Lt. Pfalzgraf was graduated from the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Lt. Pfalzgraf was graduated from the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 navigation training base of the AAF Training Command at San Marcos Army Air Field, Texas, on July 31st.

Lt. Pfalzgraf, the youngest son of Mr. and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Lt. Pfalzgraf, the youngest son of Mr. and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mrs. Pfalzgraf, was a graduate of the Woodsfield High School, class of 1939, and attended Ashland College and Ohio University, Athens. Previous to his enlistment in the U. S. Army Air Corps, he was shipping clerk at the Hercules Motor Company in Canton, O.

Lr. Pfalzgraf is survived by his parents; ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Lr. Pfalzgraf is survived by his parents; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two brothers, Fred Pfalzgraf of Cameron, and John Pfalzgraf, of Canton; and two sisters, Mrs. Ray Blachley of Canal Fulton and Miss Helen Pfalzgraf of the home.

 
1945
Source: The Zanesville Ohio Signal, dated, 20 Feb 1945
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 20 Feb 1945 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
(John Reischman was born on 25 Feb 1871 in Ohio. He died on 16 Feb 1945 in Miltonsburg, Monroe Co., OH. )
WOODSFIELD -- Funeral services were held Monday morning in St. John's Catholic Church in Miltonsburg for John Reischman with Rev. Father George F. Drescher officiating. Burial was made in the church cemetery by the Galbraith Funeral Home of Woodsfield.
Mr. Reischman died at the home of his son, Leo, on Friday [16 Feb 1945]. He is survived by two sons, Leo of the home, and Gilbert of Bridgeport. One daughter preceded him in death several years ago. Also surviving are one brother, Peter of Woodsfield Route 3 and three sisters, Mrs. Barbara Baker of Woodsfield Route 5, Mrs. Joseph Burkhart of Barnesville, and Mrs. Anna Harper of Cambridge.
 
1945 ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 1945 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 XXXXX
Pvt. Russell Morris 
Pvt. Russell Morris entered into eternal rest March 03, 1945.  Mr. And Mrs. Adolph Morris, of Lewisville, route 2, received a telegram from the war department on march 19th, stating their son, Pvt. Russell a. Morris was killed in Germany on March 3rd.
Private Morris, who entered service October 14, 1942, received his basic training in North Carolina, sailing for overseas December 26,1942. He was wounded in Italy where he spent six months in the hospital, returning to the states in February 1944. Following his recovery, he received additional training in Texas, and again sailed for overseas in February, 1945. He landed in Belgium on February 25th and on March 3rd was killed.
Russell was born July 03,1921 at Harrisville, WV. He leaves to mourn his departure, his father and mother, Adolph and Emma Morris; one brother and seven sisters, Clarence Morris and Mrs. Edna Huntsman of Belmont; Mrs. Estelle Lendon and Mrs. Vesta Morris, both of Woodsfield Route 3; Mrs. Nellie Matz of Lewisville Rt.2; Mrs. Bertha Longdon , of Louisville, KY and Nettie of the home; also a host of other relatives and friends.
 
Here at last, and over yonder
Just within the pearly gates
Watching still for loved ones coming
Now our son and brother waits.
 
When we too, shall cross the river
And on earth no longer roam
May we reunite together
Safe at last in that bright home.
 
 
January 4, 1945X

Edsel Weber

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

Edsel Weber, who recently visited his parents, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Edsel Weber, who recently visited his parents, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Weber at Lewisville, after completing his "boot" training at Great Lakes, Illinois has been sent to Wisconsin. His new address is Edsel V. Weber, S2/c, Division 61, N. T. S., University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wis.

Seaman Weber has two brothers serving in ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Seaman Weber has two brothers serving in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the Army, Sgt. Frank D. Weber is stationed in Nevada, his address being Aircraft Maintenance Squadron, Administrative Sec. C. R. A. A. B., Reno Nevada, Lt. Merle C. Weber, 0-784636, is stationed at Spence Field, Moultrie, Georgia.

 

 

March 8, 1945X

DEATH

Paul Edwin Pfalzgraf

Source: Beacon

 

Paul Edwin Pfalzgraf, youngest son of ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Paul Edwin Pfalzgraf, youngest son of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Samuel and Emma Mellott Pfalzgraf, was born at Cameron, Ohio January 16, 1922. He met his death on January 15, 1945 in an airplane accident while serving as a navigator of a B-24 somewhere in Italy.

He was a graduate of the Woodsfield High ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was a graduate of the Woodsfield High >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 School Class of 1939. He attended Ashland College and Ohio University, Athens. Prior to his service in the Air Corps he was an employee of Hercules Motor Corporation, Canton, Ohio. He enlisted in the service of his country and was sworn in at Cleveland, Ohio, September 2, 1942. On January 28, 1943, he was sent to Sheppard Field, Texas to begin his training as an aviation cadet.

His vast training took him to various ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> His vast training took him to various >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 schools; A. & M. College, Stillwater, Okla; San Antonio, Texas; Grider Field, Pine Bluff, Ark; Independence Army Air Field, Independence, Kansas; Harlingen, Texas; Selman Field, Monroe La.; and San Marcos Texas.

At San Marcos on July 31, 1944, he ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> At San Marcos on July 31, 1944, he >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 graduated as Second Lieutenant. Further training was given to the crew at Lenmoore, California, and Walla Walla, Washington

They landed in Italy some time in ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> They landed in Italy some time in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 November. He was assigned to the Fifteenth Air Force to serve as navigator at a Liberator.

Paul was an ambitious and cheerful good ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Paul was an ambitious and cheerful good >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 son; always seeing the bright side of life in everything. He obeyed the Gospel and was baptized September 2, 1940.

He was a member at the Church of Christ at ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was a member at the Church of Christ at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cameron, and lived an upright and honest life. He made the remark on his last visit home that he had learned one thing, "Do as you wish to be done by and you will have little if any trouble in life." His last letter home which was written on Sunday, January 14th, said he had been to church that day and heard a very good sermon.

He is survived by his father and mother; ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He is survived by his father and mother; >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two brothers, Fred of Cameron, and John of Canton; two sisters, Mrs. Ray Blachley (or Mary), of Canal Fulton and Miss Helen of the home; four nephews, three nieces, several aunts and uncles, numerous cousins and host of friends.

It is some small consolation to learn that ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> It is some small consolation to learn that >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Paul died without long bitter suffering, as he died instantly of the injuries which he received when the stricken ship crashed. He has been laid to rest with full military honors in an American Cemetery in Italy. The exact location of which will be made known to the family when security regulations permit.

We are thankful for Paul's twenty-three ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> We are thankful for Paul's twenty-three >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 years of a beautiful life. His part in this cruel bitter struggle is finished. "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away, Blessed be the name of the Lord."

He is not really lost to us,

Through he has passed away,

In memories that never fade

He'll live for each day.

And in the knowledge that he went

Bravely, without regret

We know he went to God content

To do the task he met.

His spirit will live on with those

Who fought for liberty

And he will be forever young

Who died to keep men free.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He is not really lost to us,

Through he has passed away,

In memories that never fade

He'll live for each day.

And in the knowledge that he went

Bravely, without regret

We know he went to God content

To do the task he met.

His spirit will live on with those

Who fought for liberty

And he will be forever young

Who died to keep men free.

>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711

 

Card of Thanks

We desire to thank our many friends and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> We desire to thank our many friends and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 neighbors for their expressions of sympathy, letters and cards; also those who called at the home and helped in any way in our deep sorrow, after the death of our son and brother. - Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Pfalzgraf and family.

1945X >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 OOOOO
Mrs. Ella B. Betts, Morgan
Mrs. Ella B. Betts, 79, passed away at 6 o'clock Tuesday morning at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Ernest Moore in Quaker City. Mrs. Betts had made her home with her daughter since the death of her husband, C. C. Betts, in January 1938. Before that time, she had always lived in Batesville. She was the daughter of Owen and Susan Roach-Morgan and was born in Batesville. She is survived by five children: Mrs. Moore with whom she lived and four sons, Richard and Ralph of Barnesville, Jess of Dayton and Charles, teacher in the Quaker city schools. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Ella B. Betts, 79, passed away at 6 o'clock Tuesday morning at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Ernest Moore in Quaker City. Mrs. Betts had made her home with her daughter since the death of her husband, C. C. Betts, in January 1938. Before that time, she had always lived in Batesville. She was the daughter of Owen and Susan Roach-Morgan and was born in Batesville. She is survived by five children: Mrs. Moore with whom she lived and four sons, Richard and Ralph of Barnesville, Jess of Dayton and Charles, teacher in the Quaker city schools. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Three children have preceded her in death. She was also survived by 14 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren. Mrs. Betts was
the last of a <<<<<<< HEAD family of seven. She was a member of the ======= family of seven. She was a member of the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Presbyterian church.
Funeral services were held Thursday afternoon at 2:30 in charge of Rev. A. A. Gilmore, pastor of the Quaker city Methodist church, at the Eberle funeral home. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral services were held Thursday afternoon at 2:30 in charge of Rev. A. A. Gilmore, pastor of the Quaker city Methodist church, at the Eberle funeral home. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Burial was made in Batesville cemetery.

He ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Charles Ackerman, aged 75, passed away at his home on West Marietta street, Saturday evening at six o clock. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 had been in failing health for several weeks but only seriously ill since last Tuesday.
He was united in marriage with ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> He was united in marriage with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Margaret Knoch, who passed away in October, 1921. He later married Lida Spence, who survives.
Also surviving besides his wife, are one daughter, Mrs. Louis R. Schumacher, of Woodsfield Rt. 1; one stepdaughter, Mrs. Clarence ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Also surviving besides his wife, are one daughter, Mrs. Louis R. Schumacher, of Woodsfield Rt. 1; one stepdaughter, Mrs. Clarence >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Lafferre, of Robinson, Illinois; one sister, Mrs. Charles Brubach, and one brother, Henry Ackerman, both of Woodsfield; also several grandchildren.

July 12, 1945X

Christman, son of Mr. Lewis P. Christman and the late Mrs. Chistman of Woodsfield, Route 3.

Mr. Christman attended the Woodsfield High School and at the present time is employed on a farm north of Woodsfield.

The newlyweds will reside in Woodsfield.

MARRIAGE
Names: Ensign Stanley K. Ward
and Miss ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Names: Ensign Stanley K. Ward
and Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Willene Piatt
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Woodsfield, Ohio, August 1945
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
On Saturday afternoon, August ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On Saturday afternoon, August >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 eighteenth, nineteen forty five, in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leland Piatt, at Graysville, Ohio, their daughter, Willene , became the bride of Ensign Stanley K. Ward, son of Mrs. Daisy Ward and the late Homer Ward, of Woodsfield.
The vows were exchanged at two-thirty oclock in the living room of the home with the Reverend James ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The vows were exchanged at two-thirty o clock in the living room of the home with the Reverend James >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Gallagher, of Barnesville, Ohio officiating at the double ring ceremony.
The bride chose her sister, Miss ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The bride chose her sister, Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Helen Piatt, as her maid of honor, and Curtis Ward, A S V-12 Unit, USNR, brother of the bridegroom served as best man.
Miss Thelma Bonar was pianist and Miss Francis Johns soloist. Miss Johns sang Always and Mendelssohns Wedding March was played for the entrance of the bride. After prayer at the close of the ceremony the soloist sang You Belong To My Heart.
The bride entered the living room on ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Miss Thelma Bonar was pianist and Miss Francis Johns soloist. Miss Johns sang Always and Mendelssohn s Wedding March was played for the entrance of the bride. After prayer at the close of the ceremony the soloist sang You Belong To My Heart.
The bride entered the living room on >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the arm of her father, who gave her in marriage.
Later the guests were invited to the ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Later the guests were invited to the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 dining room where dinner was served.
Later Ensign and Mrs. Ward left for ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Later Ensign and Mrs. Ward left for >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 a brief wedding trip in the northern part of the state.
Mrs. Ward will accompany her husband ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Ward will accompany her husband >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to New York where he will report September 1st. She will remain there until Ensign Ward is reassigned to sea duty.
Mrs. Ward is a graduate of Graysville high school, class of 41 and for the past three years has been ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Ward is a graduate of Graysville high school, class of 41 and for the past three years has been >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 employed at Foraker Brothers Store in Woodsfield.
Ensign Ward is a graduate of Woodsfield high school, class of 1942. After graduation at Anderson Aircraft School, Nashville, Tennessee, he received employment at Goodyear Aircraft, Akron, Ohio. He enlisted in the U. S. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Ensign Ward is a graduate of Woodsfield high school, class of 1942. After graduation at Anderson Aircraft School, Nashville, Tennessee, he received employment at Goodyear Aircraft, Akron, Ohio. He enlisted in the U. S. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Merchant Marine Cadet Corps and entered training at the Merchant Marine Academy, at Long Island, New York, March 12, 1943. After a brief period of training he was assigned to sea duty. He returned to the academy on March 24, 1944, and graduated December 8, 1944. He received his commission as Ensign in the U. S. Maritime Service and Ensign in the U. S. Naval Reserve.
Ensign Ward recently returned from sea duty in European waters.
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Ensign Ward recently returned from sea duty in European waters.

1945
DEATH
Name: Matilda Jane Brown Weber
Source: Newspaper of December 1945
Provided by Eloise Lumbatis January
Matilda Jane Brown Weber was born ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Matilda Jane Brown Weber was born >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 January 15, 1860, in Summit township, Monroe county, Ohio, the daughter of Isaac and Hannah Brown. She was one of seven children. She died December 14, 1945, at the age of 85 years, 10 months and 29 days.
Almost seven years ago, she fell and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Almost seven years ago, she fell and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 broke her hip and had been confined to a wheel chair, or to her bed ever since, at the home of her daughter where she had been cared for ever since her fall.
She was married to Philip Weber, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She was married to Philip Weber, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 November 13, 1881. To them were born three children: Alfred Weber, of Columbus; John H. Weber and Mrs. Rosa Fisher, at whose home she died.
She leaves to mourn her loss her ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She leaves to mourn her loss her >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 three children; seventeen grandchildren; two sisters, Mrs. Lydia Cecil, of Mechanicstown, Ohio, Mrs. Lottie Jackson, of Antioch; and one brother, Will Brown, of Ashland; also a number of other relatives and a host of friends.
At an early age she united with the Methodist Church, and later she became a member of the Buchanan Presbyterian Church. As long as her health permitted, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> At an early age she united with the Methodist Church, and later she became a member of the Buchanan Presbyterian Church. As long as her health permitted, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 she was an active member, taking an interest in all the activities of the church. She was a great reader, and a close student of the Bible. Although confined to her chair, she was always busy, with whatever tasks her hands could do.
Many people will long remember Aunt Till for the needlework she did for them. She was a lover of young people, and ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Many people will long remember Aunt Till for the needlework she did for them. She was a lover of young people, and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was always ready to care for them, as far as she was able. She kept informed on the activities of the neighborhood Sunday school and Church, and will be missed by old and young alike. Hers was not an easy life, yet she kept cheerful and helped to the end.
 
Someone has gone from this strange world ======= mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:JA'> Someone has gone from this strange world >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of ours,
No more to <<<<<<< HEAD gather its thorns with its flowers,
Loved ones have whispered that someone ======= gather its thorns with its flowers,
Loved ones have whispered that someone >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 is blest--
Free from <<<<<<< HEAD earths trials, and taking sweet rest.
======= earth s trials, and taking sweet rest. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Yes, there is one more in angelic bliss--
One less to <<<<<<< HEAD cherish, and one less to kiss.
======= cherish, and one less to kiss. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
 

September 13, 1945X

DEATH

Barbara Jackson

Source: Beacon

 

Mrs. Barbara Jackson, age 81, passed away ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Barbara Jackson, age 81, passed away >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 at her home on High Street early Monday morning at 12:30 o'clock, following an extended illness. A daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Christman, she was born in Lewisville on December 1, 1863.

She was united in marriage with John F. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She was united in marriage with John F. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Jackson in October, 1892, who preceded her in death in 1904.

At an early age she was confirmed in the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> At an early age she was confirmed in the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Evangelical Church in Lewisville and when they made their home in Woodsfield she united with the Methodist Church with her husband.

Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. Freda ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. Freda >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Sumption of Beallsville; Mrs. Ella Herriman, of the home, and Miss Sylvia Jackson, of Hubbard, O.; two step-daughters, Miss Addie Jackson and Miss Margaret Jackson, of the home; and two grandchildren Mrs. Annabelle Herriman Conkle, of the home and Miss Bronwin Sumption, of Beallsville. Six sisters and three brothers also survive: Mrs. Rosann Weber, Mrs. Louisa Christman, Miss Matida Christman, Mrs. Anna Weber, Mrs. Minnie Heft and David Christman, of Lewisville; Mrs. Mary Ackerman, Lewis Christman and George H. Christman, of Woodsfield. A brother, Jacob Christman, preceded her in death.

There are also a number of nieces and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> There are also a number of nieces and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 nephews, as well as a multitude of friends and neighbors, who held her in high esteem and mourn her passing for they have lost a friend.

Funeral services were held at two o'clock ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services were held at two o'clock >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Wednesday afternoon at the late home, with Rev. LeRoy C. Henne, of the Methodist Church, officiating. Burial was in the Moffett Cemetery on Jackson Ridge with Bauer and Turner in charge.

1946
Source: The ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Source: The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Louisville Herald, dated 14 Feb 1946
(John Zwick  was born on 04 Dec 1868 in Lewisville, Monroe Co., OH.. He died on 08 Feb 1946 in Louisville, Stark Co., OH..)
 
John ZWICK, 77, a retired farmer, died Saturday in the home of a son, Clarence Zwick of Devinney Ave., Louisville. Born in Monroe County, Mr.Zwick resided in Louisville 34 years. He was a member of St. Louis Catholic Church.
Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Emma Zwick; nine sons, Clarence, John, Harry, Homer and Francis all of Louisville, Roman of Massillon, Ralph and Marion of Canton and Edward of Harrisburg; two daughters, Mrs. A. M.Kramer and Mrs. Romia Rothermel of Canton; five brothers, Peter, George, Joseph and Charles of Lewisville, Monroe County, and Michael
of Louisville; one sister, Mrs. Rosie Smithberger of Noble County; 33 grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
The body will be taken today from the Paquelet panors to the home of Clarence Zwick.
Services will be Tuesday at 9 a.m. in St. Louis Church. Burial will be in Sacred Heart of Mary Cemetery at Harrisburg.

Their many friends extend congratulations and best wishes.

1946
Nancy Wilson Danford died at the age of 91 at the home of her daughter, Dulcie, near Salesville. She was a member of the Quaker City M.E. Church. She was buried in Friends Cemetery. At the time of her death she had 24 grandchildren, 44 great-grandchildren, and 3 great-great-grandchildren. (Obituary: 6 March, 1946 Barnesville Enterprise)

April 26, 1946

MARRIAGE

Weber-Emch

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

Tall white tapers and baskets of gladioli ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Tall white tapers and baskets of gladioli >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 formed the setting for the wedding of Miss Ella Mae Emch and Mr. Merle Weber on Thursday evening, August eighth, at seven o'clock. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Dotterer, of Rittman. The Rev. Lester E. Flauhaus, friend of the couple and pastor of the Dalton Methodist Church read the double ring service in the presence of members of the immediate families.

Mrs. Virgil DeVoe, of Lewisville, sister ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Virgil DeVoe, of Lewisville, sister >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of the groom, played throughout the ceremony. Her selections included "Bells of St. Mary's", "Because", "Always" and "I'll Walk Beside You." Mrs. Alton Weber, of Steubenville, sister-in-law of the groom, sang "Oh Promise Me," and softly hummed "I Love You Truly" as the bride approached.

Judy and Jane Emch twin nieces of the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Judy and Jane Emch twin nieces of the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 bride, were flower girls. They wore identical dresses of pink net over satin. Together they carried a silver basket filled with pink delphinium and baby's breath.

The only nephew of the groom, little two-year old Allan Weber, carried the rings on a white satin pillow. He wore a while wool suit.

Attending the bride was her close friend Miss Gladys Rupp, of Seville. Her dress was on yellow net fashioned with a sweetheart neckline and full gathered skirt. She wore a headdress of matching yellow pompons and carried a colonial bouquet of mixed flowers. She wore a link bracelet which had been presented to her ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The only nephew of the groom, little two-year old Allan Weber, carried the rings on a white satin pillow. He wore a while wool suit.

Attending the bride was her close friend Miss Gladys Rupp, of Seville. Her dress was on yellow net fashioned with a sweetheart neckline and full gathered skirt. She wore a headdress of matching yellow pompons and carried a colonial bouquet of mixed flowers. She wore a link bracelet which had been presented to her >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by the bride.

The bride designed and made her own ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The bride designed and made her own >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wedding gown which had a fitted bodice of white brocaded satin ending in a scalloped peplum. The full gathered skirt was of sheer nilonette. She wore a braided halo with a fingertip veil and carried a white Bible which she had presented to the groom while he was in the Air Corps. Attached to the Bible was a shower bouquet of white rosebuds and Stephanotis. Her jewelry was a rhinestone bracelet, a gift of the groom, and for something borrowed she wore rhinestone earrings belonging to a friend.

Edsel Weber, Lewisville served his brother as ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Edsel Weber, Lewisville served his brother as >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 best man.

The mother of the groom wore a pale green ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The mother of the groom wore a pale green >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 dress with a shoulder corsage of shaded rosebuds.

Following the ceremony a reception for the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Following the ceremony a reception for the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 seventy-five guests was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Emch, brother and sister-in-law of the bride.

The couple left later for a week's trip to ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The couple left later for a week's trip to >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Niagara Falls, Washington, D. C.. and Virginia. For traveling the bride chose a dressmaker suit of black gabardine. With it she wore white accessories and the white rosebud corsage from her bridal bouquet.

The bride is the daughter of Mr. D. E. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The bride is the daughter of Mr. D. E. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Emch of Rittman and a graduate of Wadsworth High School. Mr. Weber is the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Weber, of Lewisville and graduate of the Lewisville High School. He served three years as a pilot with Army Air Forces. They have both been employed in the offices of the Ohio Boxboard Company, in Rittman, in which city they will make their home.

1946 XXXXX
>>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Christian  Adam Matz
Christian Adam Matz was born on March 27, 1864 near Woodsfield, Ohio in Monroe County.  Christian and Lou Ellen Latta , were married on July 16, 1901 in Monroe County, Ohio by Rev. Thes. A. Hofell. Lou Ellen was born on   March 31, 1871, the daughter of John  and Mary J. Morris Latta.  Christian was a carpenter by trade. Christian, Lou Ellen  and  five children lived in Lewisville, Ohio until about 1916 when they moved to Ashland, Ohio.  Christian, age 83, passed away Saturday morning, October 12, 1946, at his home in Ashland. He suffered a stroke for two months and then followed by another stroke. Funeral services were held on Monday afternoon in  at the Gilbert funeral home in Ashland with Rev. H.H. Lentz in charge.  Burial <<<<<<< HEAD was in Ashland cemetery. Christians sisters, Rachel Christman and Elizabeth ======= was in Ashland cemetery. Christian s sisters, Rachel Christman and Elizabeth >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hines, and his brother Wm. F. Matz attended the funeral.

The new arrival has been named Brain Stephen. The grand parents are Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Christman, of Quaker City, Route 3, and E. L. Stephen of Summerfield.

Ackerman, son of Mr. Benjamin Ackerman, of Lewisville, on Saturday morning November ninth, at nine o'clock.

The wedding took place in St. John's ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> The wedding took place in St. John's >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Church of Miltonsburg at a Nuptial High Mass, with Rev. Noah E. Brunner officiating.

Miss Dorothy Stephen, of Columbus, sister ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Dorothy Stephen, of Columbus, sister >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of the bride, was the maid of honor and Mr. Francis Weisend, of Lewisville, a close friend of the groom, served as best man.

Guests present were Rev. Noah Brunner, of Miltonsburg; Mr. and Mrs. George Ackerman and son Wayne, of Parkersburg, W. Va.; Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller and family, Mrs. Elizabeth Poulton, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winland and daughter Joyce, of Barnesville; John Ackerman, Benjamin Ackerman and Francis Weisend, of Lewisville; Dorothy Stephen of Columbus; Mr. and Mrs. Marion Stephen and family, Woodsfield, Route 3; the host and hostess, Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo Carpenter; and the honored guests, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ackerman.

In the evening a reception was held in the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> In the evening a reception was held in the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Miltonsburg Parish Hall.

 

1946XXXXX

Bennett, Elias Jackson Bennett

 Source: Spirit of Democracy, Monroe County Ohio, 14 November 1946

  Well Known Evangelist Dies in Barnesville--Evangelist Elias Jackson Bennett. widely known throughout this district, died at his home at 409 Dorsey Ave., Barnesville at 11:45 a.m. Sunday following a long illness. Mr. Bennett retired from the ministry several years ago because of ill health. He was born in Monroe county, near Woodsfield on December 10, 1874, a son of Benoni S. and Margaret Mobely Bennett, and had resided in Barnesville a number of years.

  Surviving are his wife, Clara M. Bennett; four sons, George L. Bennett of Darby, PA.; Benoni F. Bennett of Denver, Colo.; Carl E. Bennett of the U.S. Merchant Marine and Lt. Col. Elias F. Bennett of Arlington, Va. Five grandchildren, one brother, Marion Bennett of Cleveland; one half-brother, Cecil Bennett of Bedford; Two sisters, Mrs. E. L. Shepherd and Mrs. Katherine Eddy of Barnesville; and a half-sister, Mrs. Ruby Friday of near Jerusalem, also survive. Mr. Bennett was a member of the W. Main Street Church of Christ in Barnesville.

  Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon in the Campbell funeral home, Barnesville, in charge of Evangelist Holly N. Smith and Evangelist Lawrence Reed. Interment was in Crestview Memorial cemetery, Barnesville. [Clara, nee McMahon, was the second wife of Elias. They had no children.]

 

1946
Jerry Richard Latta
The Canton Repository, Canton, Oh, Nov, 1946
           Jerry Richard Latta, infant son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon J. Latta of 2421 Tuscarawas St E, died Tuesday night in Mercy Hospital. The child also leaves a sister, Betty Jane of the home; the grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. D. W. Latta of Canton and Mr. and Mrs. Frank Miller of Howenstine, and the great grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. George Schaub of East Sparta and Mr. and Mrs. Clark Miller of Howenstine.
          The body is at the McCreery-Kreighbaum funeral home at East Sparta. Funeral services are planned for Thursdy afternoon conducted by Rev. D. A. Burdge.

1947 XXXXX
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> XXXXX >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Warfield, Roena Elenor (nee McMahon)
Source: Newspaper clipping, Belmont County Ohio, May 1947
  Mrs. Warfield, 89, Dies Thursday [correct is 08 May 1947]--Mrs. Roena Warfield, 89, died Thursday night at 11:30 in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Charles Adams, Neffs. The body was taken to the Walter C. Bauknecht funeral home, and will be removed to the residence of a daughter, Mrs. Clyde Dixon, Neffs. Services will be held Sunday afternoon at 2:30 in charge of Evangelist C. W. Rock, and burial will follow in Mt. Zion cemetery, Brooks Run.
  Mrs. Warfield was born near Woodsfield Dec. 24, 1857, a daughter of the late Isaac McMahon. She had resided in the Neffs vicinity for 60 years. Her husband, Joel Warfield, died 18 years ago. She was a member of the Church of Christ.
  Surviving are four daughters, Mrs. Emma Miller, Mrs. Martha F. Adams, Mrs. Lillian Ann Dixon [correct is Lydia Ann], and Mrs. Icithine Dailey [correct is Iciphene], all of Neffs; a brother William J., Barnesville, 22 grandchildren and 27 great grandchildren.
 
Christina J. Dillon nee Cline
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, June 23, 1947
Mrs. Christina Dillon, 55, wife of Charles Dillon, of New Matamoras, died Sunday morning, June 15th, at 2:30 o'clock in Marietta Memorial Hospital following her illness. She was admitted to the hospital Saturday noon.  Mrs. Dillon was born: Jan. 7, 1892 in Monroe Co. and spent the greater part of her life in the New Matamoras Community. Her parents were Marshall and Amelia Barlow Cline. She was a member of The Jericho Christian Union Church.
Surviving are her husband and twelve sons and daughters. They are: Mrs. Wm. Cross, of Woodsfield; Mrs. Wm. Huffman, Mrs. Manuel Eckelberry, Mrs. James W. Cline and Mrs. Denzil Rinardof New Matamoras; Mrs. Ralph Scott, of Alliance; Mrs. Charles Durant and Mrs. Roy Bauer, of Canton; Charles Dillon, Jr., Robert Dillon, Edwin Dillon and William Dillon, of the family home. There are 11 grand children.  Brothers and sisters are Stewart Cline, of Burlington Heights; Hershel Cline, of Griffin, Indiana; Roy Cline, of Graysville; Mrs. Alice Howell and Mrs. Olive Yost, of Woodsfield.
Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon at two o'clock at The Jericho
Church. Interment was in the cemetery nearby.
 
1947
 
Herman Jay Frank, 61, of Ridge Road, died this morning July 28, 1947 in the Bethesda Hospital where he had been a patient one day.
     Mr. Frank had been employed at Hazel-Atlas Plant No. 2.  A resident of Zanesville for the past 25 years, he attended the First Church of Nazarene but was a member of the Methodist church at Louisville [sic], O.
     Surviving are his widow, Olive Jane Frank, five sons, Elmer of Seattle, Harold of Pershing Road, Clarence, Robert and Wilfred, all of the home; two daughters, Mrs. Harry Orr of Gratiot and Miss Bonnie Frank, also of the home; five brothers, Freeman and Osal, both of Louisville [sic](Lewisville), Wesley and Price, both of Ashland, and Oscar of Woodsfield; a sister, Mrs. Rosa DeVore of Woodsfield, and six grandchildren.
     The body has been removed to the Dean-Swope funeral home.  Burial will be in Memorial Park.

Myers, performing the solemnization of vows in the First Congregational Church, Marietta, Ohio.

Elizabeth Shuman Daily Betts wife of 1st Robert Dailey; 2nd James Washington
Betts
 
On Monday, September 22, 1947, at 11:02 ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On Monday, September 22, 1947, at 11:02 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 p.m., Elizabeth Shuman Betts
passed away at the home of her daughter; Mrs. Myrl Carr, where she had made
her home for <<<<<<< HEAD the past several years. Although in ======= the past several years. Although in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 failing health for some
time, her death <<<<<<< HEAD was unexpected. She suffered a heart ======= was unexpected. She suffered a heart >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 attack and lived only
a few hours.
She was the youngest child of Margaret and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She was the youngest child of Margaret and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Jacob Shuman and born July
6, 1849, near <<<<<<< HEAD Calais, Monroe county, Ohio. She lived a ======= Calais, Monroe county, Ohio. She lived a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 long and useful
life, being 98 years, 2 months, and 16 days at the time of her death.
On November 7, 1867 she united in marriage ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On November 7, 1867 she united in marriage >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 with Robert Dailey and on
November 28, 1869 was left a widow with two small children, Oliver who died
in infancy, and Mary E. Hunt of Eldon, Ohio.
On July 12, 1872 she again united in ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> On July 12, 1872 she again united in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 marriage with James W. Betts,
moving to Batesville, Ohio where she spent most of her life. To this union
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> To this union >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
were born seven children and on December 13, 1915, death again entered her
home taking the <<<<<<< HEAD husband and father. In November, 1918, a ======= husband and father. In November, 1918, a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 son, Roy Gilbert,
was taken and in November, 1922, a daughter, Atha May Douglass.
She was blessed with 17 grandchildren and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She was blessed with 17 grandchildren and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 21 great-grandchildren, two
of each preceding her in death. Surviving are Mary E. Hunt of Eldon, Ohio,
A. J. Betts of Caldwell, Ohio, H. W. Betts of Quaker City, Oho, Emma Long of
Batesville, Ohio, Blanche Gallagher of near Batesville and Eva Carr of
Cumberland, Ohio; 15 grandchildren, 19 great-grandchildren, and a host of
relatives and friends.
She was a kind and loving and true friend, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She was a kind and loving and true friend, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 devoting her time to her
family and helping others long as health permitted. During eh last months
she suffered much, but never complained, always saying she was ready and
wanted to go <<<<<<< HEAD Home. She was always glad when friends ======= Home. She was always glad when friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 came to visit her and
will be sadly missed by those who loved her.
[Source: shared by Evelena Brown, not dated]
 
1947
Martha Viola Gatten nee Smith
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, October 23, 1947, Thursday
Mrs. Martha Viola Gatten , 72, widow of the late Winfield Gatten, died Saturday afternoon at the home of her son, Thurman Gatten, on Lewisville, Route 2, following an extended illness.
Surviving are one son, Thurman Gatten, at whose home she died; five daughters, Mrs. W. W. Willison, Mrs. Ralph Farley and Mrs. Harry Hoover of Akron; Mrs. John Cramblett and Mrs. Thomas Simmons, of Woodsfield and three brothers, Harvey Smith of Graysville and Charles and John D. Smith of Woodsfield.
Mrs. Gatten was a member of The Church of Christ.  Funeral services were held on Monday afternoon at 1:30 at the Galbraith Funeral Home, with Minister E. Gaston Collins officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery.
 

November 3, 1947X

DEATH

Addie M. Jackson

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

Miss Addie M. Jackson, age 7 passed away ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Addie M. Jackson, age 7 passed away >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 at her home on High Street on Sunday evening at 8'00 o'clock, following an extended illness.

She is survived by one sister, Miss ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> She is survived by one sister, Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Margaret Jackson of the home, three half-sisters, Mrs. Ella Herriman, of the home, Mrs. Freda Sumption of Beallsville, and Miss Sylvia Jackson of Hubbard; two nieces, Mrs. Annabel Conkle, Marysville, Tenn., and Miss Bronwin Sumption, of Beallsvile also host of other relatives and friends.

Funeral services will probably be held at ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral services will probably be held at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the home on High Street Tuesday afternoon with Rev. W. Miller, of the Woodsfield Methodist Church and Rev. Myron Ramsey, New Matamoras officiating. Interment will be in the Moffett Cemetery with Bauer & Turner in charge.

Miss Virginia Claus, niece of the bride, sang I Love You Truly and Miss Leota Christman, also a niece of the bride sang Ah, Sweet Mystery of Life.
